statements.name: PROC DATA

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: [password-option] Assigns an alter password to a SAS data file. The password allows you to protect or replace a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: DEBUG
arguments.description: Enables you to debug your program interactively by helping to identify logic errors, and sometimes data errors.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.help: FIRSTOBS=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a label for a SAS data set.

arguments.name: NESTING
arguments.description: Specifies that a note will be printed to the SAS log for the beginning and end of each DO-END and SELECT-END nesting level. This option enables you to debug mismatched DO-END and SELECT-END statements and is particularly useful in large programs where the nesting level is not obvious.

arguments.name: NOLIST
arguments.description: Suppresses the output of all variables to the SAS log when the value of _ERROR_ is 1.

arguments.name: NOMISS
arguments.description: Specifies to exclude all observations with missing values.

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.help: OBS=n | nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: PGM=
arguments.description: Names the stored compiled program that SAS creates or executes in the DATA step.

arguments.name: PW=
arguments.description: [password-option] Assigns a READ and ALTER password, both having the same value.

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: [password-option] Assigns a read password to a SAS data file. The password allows you to read or execute a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

arguments.name: SOURCE=
arguments.description: Specifies one of the following source options: SAVE, ENCRYPT, and NOSAVE.

arguments.name: SAVE
arguments.description: Saves the source code that created a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

arguments.name: ENCRYPT
arguments.description: Encrypts and saves the source code that created a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

arguments.name: NOSAVE
arguments.description: Does not save the source code.

arguments.name: STACK=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of nested LINK statements.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: Specifies that the values of the key variables must be unique.

arguments.name: VIEW=
arguments.description: Names a view that the DATA step uses to store the input DATA step view.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: Specifies specific conditions to use to select observations from a SAS data set.

arguments.name: _DATA_
arguments.description: Special SAS dataset name. Generated SAS dataset name in WORK library.

arguments.name: _LAST_
arguments.description: Special SAS dataset name. Most recently created SAS dataset.

arguments.name: _NULL_
arguments.description: Specifies that SAS does not create a data set when it executes the DATA step.

statements.name: %ELSE
statements.description: %IF expression %THEN action; <%ELSE action;>

arguments.name: %DO
arguments.description: Action statement in an %ELSE-%DO construct.

arguments.name: %GOTO
arguments.description: Jumps to a new statement.

arguments.name: %IF
arguments.description: Conditionally processes a portion of a macro.

arguments.name: %LET
arguments.description: Creates a macro variable and assigns it a value.

arguments.name: %PUT
arguments.description: Action statement in an %IF-%THEN statement. Writes text or macro variable information to the SAS log.

arguments.name: %RETURN
arguments.description: Action statement in an %IF-%THEN statement. Execution causes normal termination of the currently executing macro.

arguments.name: %THEN
arguments.description: Conditionally processes a portion of a macro.

statements.name: %IF
statements.description: Conditionally process a portion of a macro.

arguments.name: %DO
arguments.description: Action statement in a %IF-%THEN-%DO construct.

arguments.name: %GOTO
arguments.description: Jumps to a new statement.

arguments.name: %LET
arguments.description: Action statement in an %IF-%THEN statement. Creates a macro variable and assigns it a value.

arguments.name: %PUT
arguments.description: Action statement in an %IF-%THEN statement. Writes text or macro variable information to the SAS log.

arguments.name: %RETURN
arguments.description: Action statement in an %IF-%THEN statement. Execution causes normal termination of the currently executing macro.

arguments.name: %THEN
arguments.description: Conditionally process a portion of a macro.

statements.name: ABORT
statements.description: Stops executing the current DATA step, SAS job, or SAS session. n is an integer value that enables you to specify a condition code: o when used with the CANCEL argument, the value is placed in the SYSINFO automatic macro variable o when not used with the CANCEL argument, the error code that is returned by SAS is ERROR. The value of ERROR depends on the operating system. The condition code n is returned to the operating system as the final SAS system exit code.

arguments.name: <n>
arguments.description: Replace <n> with an actual integer value. n is an integer value that enables you to specify a condition code: o when used with the CANCEL argument, the value is placed in the SYSINFO automatic macro variable o when not used with the CANCEL argument, the error code that is returned by SAS is ERROR. The value of ERROR depends on the operating system. The condition code n is returned to the operating system as the final SAS system exit code.

arguments.name: ABEND
arguments.description: Causes abnormal termination of the current SAS job or session. Results depend on the method of operation: o batch mode and noninteractive mode o stops processing immediately o sends an error message to the SAS log that states that execution was terminated by the ABEND option of the ABORT macro statement o does not execute any subsequent statements or check syntax o returns control to the operating environment; further action is based on how your operating environment and your site treat jobs that end abnormally. o windowing environment and interactive line mode

arguments.name: CANCEL
arguments.description: Causes the cancellation of the current submitted statements. The results depend on the method of operation: o batch mode and noninteractive mode o The entire SAS program and SAS system are terminated. o The error message is written to the SAS log. o windowing environment and interactive line mode o It only clears the current submitted program. o Other subsequent submitted programs are not affected. o The error message is written to the SAS log. o workspace server and stored process server o It only clears currently submitted program. o Other subsequent submit calls are not affected. o The error message is written to the SAS log. o SAS IntrNet application server

arguments.name: CANCEL
arguments.description: Causes only the contents of the autoexec file or %INCLUDE file to be cleared by the %ABORT statement. Other submitted source statements will be executed after the autoexec or %INCLUDE file.

arguments.name: NOLIST
arguments.description: Suppresses the output of all variables to the SAS log. Requirement: NOLIST must be the last option in the ABORT statement.

arguments.name: RETURN
arguments.description: Causes abnormal termination of the current SAS job or session. Results depend on the method of operation: o batch mode and noninteractive mode o stops processing immediately o sends an error message to the SAS log that states that execution was terminated by the RETURN option in the ABORT macro statement o does not execute any subsequent statements or check syntax o returns control to the operating environment with a condition code indicating an error. o windowing environment and interactive line mode

statements.name: ARRAY
statements.description: Defines the elements of an array.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: Specifies all variables.

arguments.name: _CHARACTER_
arguments.description: Specifies all character variables.

arguments.name: _NUMERIC_
arguments.description: Specifies all numeric variables.

arguments.name: _TEMPORARY_
arguments.description: Creates a list of temporary data elements.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Controls the operation of a SET, MERGE, MODIFY, or UPDATE statement in the DATA step and sets up special grouping variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the data sets are sorted in descending order by the variable that is specified. DESCENDING means largest to smallest numerically, or reverse alphabetical for character variables.

arguments.name: GROUPFORMAT
arguments.description: Uses the formatted values, instead of the internal values, of the BY variables to determine where BY groups begin and end, and therefore how FIRST.variable and LAST.variable are assigned. Although the GROUPFORMAT option can appear anywhere in the BY statement, the option applies to all variables in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations with the same BY value are grouped together but are not necessarily sorted in alphabetical or numeric order.

statements.name: CALL
statements.description: Invokes a SAS CALL routine.

statements.name: CONTINUE
statements.description: Stops processing the current DO-loop iteration and resumes processing the next iteration.

statements.name: DATALINES4
statements.description: Indicates that data lines that contain semicolons follow.

statements.name: DATALINES
statements.description: Specifies that data lines follow.

statements.name: DELETE
statements.description: Stops processing the current observation.

statements.name: DESCRIBE
statements.description: Retrieves source code from a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

statements.name: DISPLAY
statements.description: Displays a window that is created with the WINDOW statement.

arguments.name: BELL
arguments.description: Produces an audible alarm, beep, or bell sound when the window is displayed if your personal computer is equipped with a speaker device that provides sound.

arguments.name: BLANK
arguments.description: Clears the window.

arguments.name: DELETE
arguments.description: Deletes the display of the window after processing passes from the DISPLAY statement on which the option appears.

arguments.name: NOINPUT
arguments.description: Specifies that you cannot input values into fields that are displayed in the window.

arguments.name: BY
arguments.description: Precedes an increment integer (other than 0) or an expression that generates an integer to be added to the value of the index variable in each iteration of the DO loop.

arguments.name: TO
arguments.description: Separates the start and stop integers or expressions that control the number of times the portion of the DATA step between the iterative DO and END statements is processed.

arguments.name: UNTIL
arguments.description: ...more SAS statements... END

statements.name: DROP
statements.description: Excludes variables from output SAS data sets.

statements.name: ELSE
statements.description: If the condition in an IF-THEN statement is false and an ELSE statement is present, then the ELSE action is carried out.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN-ELSE construct. Specifies a group of statements to be executed as a unit.

arguments.name: IF
arguments.description: Executes a SAS statement for observations that meet specific conditions.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN-ELSE construct. Writes the current observation to a SAS data set.

arguments.name: PUT
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN-ELSE construct. Writes lines to the SAS log, to the SAS output window, or to an external location that is specified in the most recent FILE statement.

arguments.name: THEN
arguments.description: If the conditions that are specified in the IF clause are met, the IF-THEN statement executes a SAS statement for observations that are read from a SAS data set, for records in an external file, or for computed values.

statements.name: END
statements.description: Ends a DO group or SELECT group processing.

statements.name: ENDDATA
statements.description: [This statement is valid only in DS2 and HPDS2 procedures.] The ENDDATA statement terminates the DS2 code block. The statements between the DATA and ENDDATA statement are submitted to the grid for execution. The DS2 run, init, and term methods are specified between the DATA and ENDDATA statements.

statements.name: ENDPACKAGE
statements.description: Marks the end of a PACKAGE statement. Although the ENDPACKAGE statement is not required, it can make the code easier to read.

statements.name: ENDRSUBMIT
statements.description: Marks the end of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session for execution.

statements.name: ENDTABLE
statements.description: Marks the end of a TABLE statement.

statements.name: ENDTHREAD
statements.description: Marks the end of a THREAD statement. Although the ENDTHREAD statement is not required, it can make the code easier to read.

statements.name: ERROR
statements.description: Sets _ERROR_ to 1. A message written to the SAS log is optional.

statements.name: EXECUTE
statements.description: Executes a stored compiled DATA step program.

statements.name: FILE
statements.description: where file-specification identifies an external file that the DATA step uses to write output from a PUT statement. File-specification can have these forms: 'external-file' specifies the physical name of an external file, which is enclosed in quotation marks. The physical name is the name by which the operating environment recognizes the file. fileref specifies the fileref of an external file. Requirement: You must have previously associated fileref with an external file in a FILENAME statement or function, or in an appropriate operating environment command. There is only one exception to this rule: when you use the FILEVAR= option, the fileref is simply a placeholder. fileref(file) specifies a fileref that is previously assigned to an external file that is an aggregate grouping of files. Follow the fileref with the name of a file or member, which is enclosed in parentheses. LOG is a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements to the SAS log. PRINT is a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements to the same file as the output that is produced by SAS procedures. device-type specifies the type of device or the access method that is used if the fileref points to an input or output device or a location that is not a physical file: DISK, DUMMY, GTERM, PIPE, PLOTTER, PRINTER, TAPE, TEMP, TERMINAL, UPRINTER. type specifies the type of file in z/OS: DLI, HFS, MVS, PIPE, VSAM. operating-environment-options or host-options Additional specifications might be required when you specify some devices. See the SAS documentation for your operating environment before specifying a value other than DISK. Values in addition to the ones listed here might be available in some operating environments.

arguments.name: ALQ=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the number of blocks initially allocated to an external file when it is created. The value can range from 0 to 2,147,483,647. If the value is 0 (the default), the minimum number of blocks required for the given file format is used.

arguments.name: BLKSIZE=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the number of bytes that are physically read or written in an I/O operation. The default is 8K. The maximum is 1M (Windows) or 1G-1(UNIX).

arguments.name: BLOCK
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates whether the client is to wait if no data is currently available. BLOCK is the default value.

arguments.name: BOM
arguments.description: [UNIX/z/OS Host Option] Includes a Byte Order Mark when a UNICODE-encoded file is created.

arguments.name: BUFND=
arguments.description: Indicates how many data buffers to use for the VSAM data set.

arguments.name: BUFNI=
arguments.description: Indicates how many index buffers to use for the VSAM data set.

arguments.name: BYTE
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates the type of pipe. BYTE is the default value.

arguments.name: CC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the carriage-control format of the SAS log and the procedure output file.

arguments.name: FORTRAN
arguments.description: Indicates FORTRAN carriage-control format. This is the default for print files.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Indicates OpenVMS print format.

arguments.name: CR
arguments.description: Indicates OpenVMS carriage-return, carriage-control format. This is the default for nonprinting files.

arguments.name: CLIENT
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option specifies the mode of a named pipe. The default value is SERVER.

arguments.name: CLOSE=
arguments.description: [z/OS Host Option] Indicates how a tape volume is positioned at the end of the DATA step.

arguments.name: REREAD
arguments.description: Positions the tape at the logical beginning of the data set.

arguments.name: LEAVE
arguments.description: Positions the tape at the logical end of the data set.

arguments.name: REWIND
arguments.description: Rewinds the tape to the physical beginning of the volume.

arguments.name: FREE
arguments.description: Dynamically deallocates the tape volume.

arguments.name: DISP
arguments.description: Is implied by the control language.

arguments.name: COLUMN=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS automatically sets to the current column location of the pointer.

arguments.name: COMMAND
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Allows remote commands to be issued to DDE server applications that not use the SYSTEM topic name.

arguments.name: CSRC
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies that you want to use the CSRCESRV services (available with z/OS) to compress data on output. For example: data _null_; file myfile csrc; put ... ; run;

arguments.name: DCB=
arguments.description: specifies the fileref of an external file that was referenced in an earlier FILE or INFILE statement in the same DATA step. SAS uses that file's RECFM=, LRECL=, and BLKSIZE= information for the current file.

arguments.name: DELIMITER=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST output.

arguments.name: DEQ=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the number of blocks added when OpenVMS RMS automatically extends an external file during a write operation. The value can range from 0 to 65,535. The default value is 0, telling OpenVMS RMS to use the process's default value. A large value results in fewer file extensions over the life of the file; a small value results in numerous file extensions over the life of the file. A file with numerous file extensions might be noncontiguous, thereby slowing record access.

arguments.name: DEVTYPE=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable (minimum length 24) that SAS sets to the device type. SAS obtains the device type by using the z/OS operating environment DEVTYPE macro.

arguments.name: DISK
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies that the device is a disk drive.

arguments.name: DLI
arguments.description: [type] For IMS-DL/I databases.

arguments.name: DLMSOPT=
arguments.description: Specifies a parsing option for the DLMSTR= T option that removes trailing blanks of the string delimiter.

arguments.name: 'T'
arguments.description: Removes trailing blanks of the string delimiter.

arguments.name: DLMSTR=
arguments.description: Specifies a character string as an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST output

arguments.name: DROPOVER
arguments.description: Discards data items that exceed the output line length (as specified by the LINESIZE= or LRECL= options in the FILE statement).

arguments.name: DSCB=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable (minimum length 96) that SAS sets to the Data Set Control Block (DSCB) information from a non-VSAM data set.

arguments.name: DSD
arguments.description: Specifies that data values that contain embedded delimiters, such as tabs or commas, be enclosed in quotation marks.

arguments.name: DUMMY
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies that the output to the file is discarded. Tip: Specifying DUMMY can be useful for testing.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Specifies the encoding to use when writing to the output file.

arguments.name: 'warabic'
arguments.description: Arabic

arguments.name: 'wbaltic'
arguments.description: Baltic

arguments.name: 'wlatin2'
arguments.description: Central Europe

arguments.name: 'wcyrillic'
arguments.description: Cyrillic

arguments.name: 'wgreek'
arguments.description: Greek

arguments.name: 'whebrew'
arguments.description: Hebrew

arguments.name: 'wturkish'
arguments.description: Turkish

arguments.name: 'wvietnamese'
arguments.description: Vietnamese

arguments.name: 'wlatin1'
arguments.description: Western

arguments.name: 'utf-8'
arguments.description: Unicode encoding

arguments.name: 'ms-950'
arguments.description: Traditional Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-936'
arguments.description: Simplified Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-932'
arguments.description: Japanese

arguments.name: 'ms-949'
arguments.description: Korean

arguments.name: EOFCONNECT
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes and is valid only when you are defining the server. This option indicates that if an end-of-file (EOF) character is received from a client, the server should try to connect to the next client.

arguments.name: FAC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Overrides the default file access attributes used for external files. Use this option to indicate the level of access you want to allow for an external file. You can allow READ, WRITE, UPDATE, and DELETE access (as well as no access). By default with external files, files opened for input allow read access, files opened for output allow WRITE access, and files opened for update allow READ and WRITE access. The form of the FAC= option is FAC=access-option-list where access-option-list can be one of the following: DEL specifies DELETE access. GET specifies READ access. PUT specifies WRITE access. UPD specifies UPDATE access. You can combine these values in any order. For example, specifying the following indicates that you want DELETE, READ, and WRITE access:

arguments.name: FEEDBACK=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that SAS sets to the VSAM logical error code. This option is similar to the _FDBK_ automatic variable. When SAS sets the FEEDBACK variable, you must reset it to 0 in order to continue.

arguments.name: FILEDATA=
arguments.description: [UNIX/z/OS Host Option] The FILEDATA= option specifies that the file being processed is expected to contain either binary or text data.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: The FILEDATA= option specifies that the file being processed is expected to contain binary data.

arguments.name: TEXT
arguments.description: The FILEDATA= option specifies that the file being processed is expected to contain text data.

arguments.name: FILENAME=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable, whose name you supply, that SAS sets to the value of the physical name of the file currently open for PUT statement output.

arguments.name: FILEVAR=
arguments.description: Defines a variable whose change in value causes the FILE statement to close the current output file and open a new one the next time the FILE statement executes.

arguments.name: FLOWOVER
arguments.description: Causes data that exceeds the current line length to be written on a new line.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTES
arguments.description: Specifies that the currently defined footnotes are printed.

arguments.name: GSFCC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the file format of graphic stream files (GSF files). When specified in the FILENAME statement, it affects only the GSF files that are created using that fileref.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Creates a GSF file. It is a VFC format file with carriage control set to null. These files can be used with most utilities with the exception of some file transfer protocols, such as Kermit. This is the default value for this option.

arguments.name: CR
arguments.description: Creates a carriage return carriage control file.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Creates a file with no carriage control. This format is useful if you plan to download the file to a personal computer.

arguments.name: GTERM
arguments.description: [device-type] Indicates that the output device type is a graphics device that will receive graphics data.

arguments.name: HEADER=
arguments.description: Defines a statement label that identifies a group of SAS statements that you want to execute each time SAS begins a new output page

arguments.name: HFS
arguments.description: [type] For UNIX System Services files.

arguments.name: HOTLINK
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Instructs SAS to use the DDE HOTLINK.

arguments.name: IGNOREDOSEOF
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used in the context of I/O operations on variable record format files. When this option is specified, any occurrence of ^Z is interpreted as character data and not as an end-of-file marker.

arguments.name: JFCB=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable (minimum length 176) that SAS sets to the Job File Control Block (JFCB).

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies which key SAS uses to read the records in an RMS file with indexed organization. The KEY= option is always used with the KEYVALUE= option.

arguments.name: KEYLEN=
arguments.description: Specifies a numeric SAS variable that, when used with GENKEY, specifies the length of the key that is to be compared to the keys in the file.

arguments.name: KEYPOS=
arguments.description: Indicates the numeric variable that SAS sets to the position of the VSAM key field. This option enables you to read keys without knowing the key position in advance. This variable is set to the column number (starting from 1).

arguments.name: KEYVALUE=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the key value with which to begin reading an indexed file.

arguments.name: LINE=
arguments.description: Defines a variable whose value is the current relative line number within the group of lines available to the output pointer.

arguments.name: LINESIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the maximum number of columns per line for reports and the maximum record length for data files.

arguments.name: LINESLEFT=
arguments.description: Defines a variable whose value is the number of lines left on the current page.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Is a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements to the SAS log.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: Specifies the logical record length of the output file.

arguments.name: MBC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the size of the I/O buffers that OpenVMS RMS allocates for a particular file. The value can range from 0 to 127 and represents the number of blocks used for each buffer. By default, this option is set to 0 and the default values for the process are used. The MBC= option (multiblock count) is used for both input and output to control the allocation for a particular file. If you want to control the allocation size for all the external files used during the current SAS session, you can use the MBC= option in every FILE, FILENAME, or INFILE statement. You can also use the DCL SET RMS_DEFAULT command to specify a process default, and let the SAS values default to the process's default values.

arguments.name: MBF=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the number of I/O buffers you want OpenVMS RMS to allocate for a particular file. The value can range from 0 to 127 and represents the number of buffers used. By default, this option is set to a value of 2. If a value of 0 is specified, the default value for the process is used. The MBF= option (multibuffer count) is used for both input and output to control the number of buffers allocated for a particular file. If you want to control the number of buffers allocated for all the external files used during the SAS session, you can use the MBF= option in every FILE, FILENAME, or INFILE statement. The DCL SET RMS_DEFAULT command can be used to specify a process default. Then, you can let the SAS values default to the process's default values.

arguments.name: MESSAGE
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates the type of pipe. BYTE is the default value.

arguments.name: MOD
arguments.description: Writes the output lines after any existing lines in the file.

arguments.name: MVS
arguments.description: [type] For z/OS data sets.

arguments.name: N=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that you want available to the output pointer in the current iteration of the DATA step.

arguments.name: <n>
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that are available to the output pointer. Replace n with an integer.

arguments.name: PAGESIZE
arguments.description: Specifies that the entire page is available to the output pointer.

arguments.name: NOBLOCK
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates whether the client is to wait if no data is currently available. BLOCK is the default value.

arguments.name: NOBOM
arguments.description: [UNIX/z/OS Host Option] Specifies that a Byte Order Mark is not included when a UNICODE-encoded file is created.

arguments.name: NOFOOTNOTES
arguments.description: Specifies that the currently defined footnotes are not printed.

arguments.name: NOPAD
arguments.description: Specifies that records written to an external file are not padded with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Specifies that carriage-control characters are placed in the output lines.

arguments.name: NOTAB
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Instructs SAS to ignore tab characters between variables.

arguments.name: NOTITLES
arguments.description: Specifies that the current title lines are not printed on the pages of files.

arguments.name: ODS=
arguments.description: Specifies to use the Output Delivery System to format the output from a DATA step.

arguments.name: OLD
arguments.description: Replaces the previous contents of the file.

arguments.name: PAD
arguments.description: Specifies that records written to an external file are padded with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: PAGESIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the number of lines per page for your reports.

arguments.name: PASSWD=
arguments.description: Gives the appropriate password for a VSAM data set that has password protection.

arguments.name: PIPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unnamed pipe. Note: Some operating environments do not support pipes.

arguments.name: PLOTTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unbuffered graphics output device.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Either a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements to the same file as the output that is produced by SAS procedures, or an option that specifies that carriage-control characters are placed in the output lines.

arguments.name: PRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a printer or printer spool file.

arguments.name: RC4STOP
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Stops the DATA step from executing if a return code greater than 4 is returned by the operating environment when the VSAM data set is opened.

arguments.name: RECFM=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX/z/OS Host Option] Specifies the record format of the external file. Under z/OS, the following values can be appended to the RECFM values:
arguments.help: RECFM=F | P | S | V|D | N | s370V | S370VB | S370VBS | STREAMLF | FB | VB | U

arguments.name: F
arguments.description: Fixed-record format

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: Print format.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: Stream-record format.

arguments.name: V
arguments.description: Variable-record format (the default)

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Indicates binary format and causes the file to be treated as a byte stream. If LRECL is not specified, by default SAS reads 256 bytes at a time from the file.

arguments.name: s370V
arguments.description: Indicates the variable S370 record format (V).

arguments.name: S370VB
arguments.description: Indicates the variable block S370 record format (VB).

arguments.name: S370VBS
arguments.description: Indicates the variable block with spanned records S370 record format (VBS).

arguments.name: STREAMLF
arguments.description: [For OpenVMS] Specifies StreamLF record format. Records are delimited by LF.

arguments.name: FB
arguments.description: Specifies fixed-length records, blocked.

arguments.name: VB
arguments.description: Specifies variable-length records, blocked.

arguments.name: U
arguments.description: Specifies undefined-length records, unblocked.

arguments.name: RECORDS=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that SAS sets to the number of logical records in a VSAM data set that has been opened for input.

arguments.name: RECORG=
arguments.description: [z/OS Host Option] Specifies the organization of records in a new VSAM data set. Use this option only if SMS is active.

arguments.name: KS
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM key-sequenced data set.

arguments.name: ES
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM entry-sequenced data set.

arguments.name: RR
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM relative-record data set.

arguments.name: LS
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM linear-space data set.

arguments.name: RESET
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Indicates that the VSAM file is reset to empty (no records) when it is opened. This option applies only to loading a VSAM data set that has been marked REUSE. You cannot use this option if the data set contains an alternate index.

arguments.name: RETRY=
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option]

arguments.name: RRN=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that you set to the relative record number (RRN) of the record that you want to read or write. This option indicates that keyed direct access is being used; it is appropriate for RRDS only.

arguments.name: SERVER
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option specifies the mode of a named pipe. The default value is SERVER.

arguments.name: SHR=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Overrides the default file-sharing attributes used for external files. With this option, you can indicate the access level you want to give other users. You can allow READ, WRITE, UPDATE, and DELETE access (as well as no access). By default with external files, files opened for input allow shared read access, and files opened for output or UPDATE do not allow shared access. However, you can allow other users to have READ and WRITE access to a file that you are opening for input only. To accomplish this, use the SHR= option. The syntax of the SHR= option is SHR=share-option-list where share-option-list can be one of the following: DEL specifies DELETE access. GET specifies shared READ access. NONE specifies no shared access. PUT specifies shared WRITE access. UPD specifies UPDATE access. You can combine these values in any order. For example, specifying the following indicates that you want shared DELETE, READ, and WRITE access:

arguments.name: STOPOVER
arguments.description: Stops processing the DATA step immediately if a PUT statement attempts to write a data item that exceeds the current line length.

arguments.name: TAPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a tape drive.

arguments.name: TEMP
arguments.description: [device-type] Creates a temporary file that exists only as long as the filename is assigned.

arguments.name: TERMINAL
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies the user's terminal.

arguments.name: TERMSTR=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the end-of-line character for the file. Use this option to share files between the UNIX and Windows operating environments.
arguments.help: TERMSTR=CR | CRLF | LF | NULL | NONE | NL | LFCR | CRNL

arguments.name: CR
arguments.description: Carriage return (CR).

arguments.name: CRLF
arguments.description: Carriage return (CR) followed by line feed (LF).

arguments.name: LF
arguments.description: Line feed only (the default).

arguments.name: NULL
arguments.description: NULL character (0x00).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Record terminators are not used. This parameter provides the same function as FILEDATA=BINARY.

arguments.name: NL
arguments.description: The newline character (x'15') is used as the record terminator. This parameter provides the same function as FILEDATA=TEXT.

arguments.name: LFCR
arguments.description: The sequence LF followed by CR is used as the record terminator.

arguments.name: CRNL
arguments.description: The sequence CR followed by NL is used as the record terminator.

arguments.name: TITLES
arguments.description: Specifies that the current title lines are printed on the pages of files.

arguments.name: UCBNAME=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable (minimum length 3) that SAS sets to the unit name (device address), which is derived from information in the unit control block (UCB).

arguments.name: UNBUF
arguments.description: [UNIX Host Option] Tells SAS not to perform buffered writes to the file on any subsequent FILE statement. This option applies especially when you are reading from or writing to a data collection device. As explained in SAS Language Reference: Dictionary, it also prevents buffered reads on INFILE statements.

arguments.name: UPRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a Universal Printing printer definition name.

arguments.name: VOLUME=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable (with a minimum length of six characters) that SAS sets to the tape VOLSER or the disk volume serial number. In the case of a multivolume file, the VOLUME= variable contains the concatenated volume serial numbers up to the length of the variable or the first 30 volumes, whichever is less. The value in the VOLUME= variable contains the volume serial number of the first data set in the concatenation when the file is opened. This serial number changes if you open a subsequent data set in the concatenation.

arguments.name: VSAM
arguments.description: [type] For VSAM files.

arguments.name: _FILE_=
arguments.description: Names a character variable that references the current output buffer of this FILE statement.

statements.name: GO TO
statements.description: Jumps to a new statement.

arguments.name: CALL
arguments.description: Invokes a SAS CALL routine.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN construct.

arguments.name: GO
arguments.description: Jumps to a new statement.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN construct.

arguments.name: PUT
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN construct. Writes lines to the SAS log, to the SAS output window, or to an external location that is specified in the most recent FILE statement.

arguments.name: RETURN
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN construct. Stops executing statements at the current point in the DATA step and returns to a predetermined point in the step.

arguments.name: SET
arguments.description: Reads an observation from one or more SAS data sets.

arguments.name: STOP
arguments.description: Action statement in an IF-THEN construct. Stops execution of the current DATA step.

arguments.name: THEN
arguments.description: If the conditions that are specified in the IF clause are met, the IF-THEN statement executes a SAS statement for observations that are read from a SAS data set, for records in an external file, or for computed values.

arguments.name: WHEN
arguments.description: WHEN statement in an IF-THEN-WHEN construct.

statements.name: INFILE
statements.description: file-specification identifies a file in one of the following forms: fileref specifies the assigned fileref or the allocated ddname of the file. A fileref must conform to the rules for ddnames. That is, it can consist of up to eight letters, numbers, or national characters ($, @, and #) and underscores (_). The first character must be either a letter or a national character. fileref(member) specifies a member of a partitioned data set, where the PDS or PDSE is specified by the assigned fileref or allocated ddname. If you specify a fileref that is not allocated, then SAS attempts to construct a data set name with the following three qualifiers: o the value of the SYSPREF= option (usually the user ID) o the specified fileref o DATA If a file is found that has this constructed data set name, then SAS opens it and reads it. The value of the FILEEXT= system option can affect the way SAS interprets PDS and PDSE member names. 'physical-filename' specifies a physical file, which can be a member of a partitioned data set (PDS), an extended partitioned data set (PDSE), or a UNIX System Services file, using the following syntax: o a fully qualified data set name. For example: 'myid.raw.datax' o a fully qualified data set name with a member in parentheses. For example: 'sas.raw.data(mem1)' o a partially qualified data set name with a period preceding it. For example: '.raw.data' o a partially qualified data set name with a period preceding it and a member name in parentheses. For example: '.raw.data(mem1)' o for PDS members, a fully or partially qualified data set name with a wildcard name in parentheses. For example: '.raw.data(mem*)', '.raw.data(*mem1)', '.raw.data(*)' o a UNIX System Services file. For example: '/u/userid/raw' or 'HFS:raw' or '/u/userid/data/*'

arguments.name: BACKWARD
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Causes SAS to read the VSAM data set backwards (INFILE only)

arguments.name: BLKSIZE=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the number of bytes that are physically read or written in an I/O operation. The default is 8K. The maximum is 1M (Windows) or 1G-1(UNIX).

arguments.name: BLOCK
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates whether the client is to wait if no data is currently available. BLOCK is the default value.

arguments.name: BUFND=
arguments.description: Indicates how many data buffers to use for the VSAM data set.

arguments.name: BUFNI=
arguments.description: Indicates how many index buffers to use for the VSAM data set.

arguments.name: BYTE
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates the type of pipe. BYTE is the default value.

arguments.name: CCHHR=
arguments.description: specifies a character variable to which the physical address (cylinder head record) of a record is returned. This applies to files on CKD disks only.

arguments.name: CLIENT
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option specifies the mode of a named pipe. The default value is SERVER.

arguments.name: CLOSE=
arguments.description: [z/OS Host Option] Indicates how a tape volume is positioned at the end of the DATA step.

arguments.name: REREAD
arguments.description: Positions the tape at the logical beginning of the data set.

arguments.name: LEAVE
arguments.description: Positions the tape at the logical end of the data set.

arguments.name: REWIND
arguments.description: Rewinds the tape to the physical beginning of the volume.

arguments.name: FREE
arguments.description: Dynamically deallocates the tape volume.

arguments.name: DISP
arguments.description: Is implied by the control language.

arguments.name: COLUMN=
arguments.description: Names a variable that SAS uses to assign the current column location of the input pointer. Like automatic variables, the COLUMN= variable is not written to the data set.

arguments.name: CONTROLINTERVAL
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Indicates that you want to read physical VSAM control interval records rather than logical records. This option is typically used for diagnostic purposes (INFILE only).

arguments.name: CSRC
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies that you want to use the CSRCESRV services (available with z/OS) to compress data on output. For example: data _null_; file myfile csrc; put ... ; run;

arguments.name: CVAF
arguments.description: [VTOC Option under z/OS] Tells SAS to use the Common VTOC Access Facility (CVAF) of the IBM program product Data Facility/Device Support (DF/DS) for indexed VTOCs. If the VTOC is not indexed, or if your installation does not have CVAF, this option is ignored.

arguments.name: DATALINES4
arguments.description: Specifies that the input data immediately follows the DATALINES4|CARDS4 statement in the DATA step. Using DATALINES4|CARDS4 allows you to use the INFILE statement options to control how the INPUT statement reads instream data lines.

arguments.name: DATALINES
arguments.description: Specifies that the input data immediately follows the DATALINES|CARDS statement in the DATA step. Using DATALINES|CARDS allows you to use the INFILE statement options to control how the INPUT statement reads instream data lines.

arguments.name: DCB=
arguments.description: specifies the fileref of an external file that was referenced in an earlier FILE or INFILE statement in the same DATA step. SAS uses that file's RECFM=, LRECL=, and BLKSIZE= information for the current file.

arguments.name: DELIMITER=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST input.

arguments.name: DISK
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies that the device is a disk drive.

arguments.name: DLI
arguments.description: [type] For IMS-DL/I databases.

arguments.name: DLMSOPT=
arguments.description: Specifies whether case-insensitive comparisons will be done, or trailing blanks of the string delimiter will be removed.

arguments.name: 'I'
arguments.description: Specifies that case-insensitive comparisons will be done.

arguments.name: 'T'
arguments.description: Specifies that trailing blanks of the string delimiter will be removed.

arguments.name: DLMSTR=
arguments.description: Specifies a character string as an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST input

arguments.name: DSD
arguments.description: Specifies that when data values are enclosed in quotation marks, delimiters within the value are treated as character data. The DSD option changes how SAS treats delimiters when you use LIST input and sets the default delimiter to a comma. When you specify DSD, SAS treats two consecutive delimiters as a missing value and removes quotation marks from character values.

arguments.name: DUMMY
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies that the output to the file is discarded. Tip: Specifying DUMMY can be useful for testing.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Specifies the encoding to use when reading from the external file.

arguments.name: 'warabic'
arguments.description: Arabic

arguments.name: 'wbaltic'
arguments.description: Baltic

arguments.name: 'wlatin2'
arguments.description: Central Europe

arguments.name: 'wcyrillic'
arguments.description: Cyrillic

arguments.name: 'wgreek'
arguments.description: Greek

arguments.name: 'whebrew'
arguments.description: Hebrew

arguments.name: 'wturkish'
arguments.description: Turkish

arguments.name: 'wvietnamese'
arguments.description: Vietnamese

arguments.name: 'wlatin1'
arguments.description: Western

arguments.name: 'utf-8'
arguments.description: Unicode encoding

arguments.name: 'ms-950'
arguments.description: Traditional Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-936'
arguments.description: Simplified Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-932'
arguments.description: Japanese

arguments.name: 'ms-949'
arguments.description: Korean

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to 1 when the current input data record is the last in the input file. Until SAS processes the last data record, the END= variable is set to 0. Like automatic variables, this variable is not written to the data set. Restriction: You cannot use the END= option with UNBUFFERED option, DATALINES or DATALINES4 statement, and an INPUT statement that reads multiple input data records.

arguments.name: EOF=
arguments.description: Specifies a statement label that is the object of an implicit GO TO when the INFILE statement reaches end of file.

arguments.name: EOFCONNECT
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes and is valid only when you are defining the server. This option indicates that if an end-of-file (EOF) character is received from a client, the server should try to connect to the next client.

arguments.name: EOV=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to 1 when the first record in a file in a series of concatenated files is read.

arguments.name: ERASE=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric SAS variable that you must set to 1 when you want to erase a VSAM record (INFILE only).

arguments.name: EXPANDTABS
arguments.description: Specifies to expand tab characters to the standard tab setting, which is set at 8-column intervals that start at column 9.

arguments.name: FAC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Overrides the default file access attributes used for external files. Use this option to indicate the level of access you want to allow for an external file. You can allow READ, WRITE, UPDATE, and DELETE access (as well as no access). By default with external files, files opened for input allow read access, files opened for output allow WRITE access, and files opened for update allow READ and WRITE access. The form of the FAC= option is FAC=access-option-list where access-option-list can be one of the following: DEL specifies DELETE access. GET specifies READ access. PUT specifies WRITE access. UPD specifies UPDATE access. You can combine these values in any order. For example, specifying the following indicates that you want DELETE, READ, and WRITE access:

arguments.name: FEEDBACK=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that SAS sets to the VSAM logical error code. This option is similar to the _FDBK_ automatic variable. When SAS sets the FEEDBACK variable, you must reset it to 0 in order to continue.

arguments.name: FILEDATA=
arguments.description: [UNIX/z/OS Host Option] The FILEDATA= option specifies that the file being processed is expected to contain either binary or text data.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: The FILEDATA= option specifies that the file being processed is expected to contain binary data.

arguments.name: TEXT
arguments.description: The FILEDATA= option specifies that the file being processed is expected to contain text data.

arguments.name: FILENAME=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to the physical StatementOptionName of the currently opened input file. Like automatic variables, the FILENAME= variable is not written to the data set.

arguments.name: FILEVAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable whose change in value causes the INFILE statement to close the current input file and open a new one.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.description: Specifies a record number that SAS uses to begin reading input data records in the input file.

arguments.name: FLOWOVER
arguments.description: Causes an INPUT statement to continue to read the next input data record if it does not find values in the current input line for all the variables in the statement.

arguments.name: GENKEY
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Causes SAS to use the KEY= variable as the leading portion of a record's key. VSAM retrieves the first record whose key matches the generic key (INFILE only).

arguments.name: GTERM
arguments.description: [device-type] Indicates that the output device type is a graphics device that will receive graphics data.

arguments.name: HFS
arguments.description: [type] For UNIX System Services files.

arguments.name: HOTLINK
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Instructs SAS to use the DDE HOTLINK.

arguments.name: IDMS
arguments.description: [type] For CA-IDMS files.

arguments.name: IGNOREDOSEOF
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used in the context of I/O operations on variable record format files. When this option is specified, any occurrence of ^Z is interpreted as character data and not as an end-of-file marker.

arguments.name: ISAM
arguments.description: [type] For ISAM files.

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies which key SAS uses to read the records in an RMS file with indexed organization. The KEY= option is always used with the KEYVALUE= option.

arguments.name: KEYLEN=
arguments.description: Specifies a numeric SAS variable that, when used with GENKEY, specifies the length of the key that is to be compared to the keys in the file.

arguments.name: KEYPOS=
arguments.description: Indicates the numeric variable that SAS sets to the position of the VSAM key field. This option enables you to read keys without knowing the key position in advance. This variable is set to the column number (starting from 1).

arguments.name: KEYVALUE=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the key value with which to begin reading an indexed file.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to the length of the current input line.

arguments.name: LINE=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to the line location of the input pointer in the input buffer. Like automatic variables, the LINE= variable is not written to the data set.

arguments.name: LINESIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the record length that is available to the INPUT statement.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: Specifies the logical record length.

arguments.name: MBC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the size of the I/O buffers that OpenVMS RMS allocates for a particular file. The value can range from 0 to 127 and represents the number of blocks used for each buffer. By default, this option is set to 0 and the default values for the process are used. The MBC= option (multiblock count) is used for both input and output to control the allocation for a particular file. If you want to control the allocation size for all the external files used during the current SAS session, you can use the MBC= option in every FILE, FILENAME, or INFILE statement. You can also use the DCL SET RMS_DEFAULT command to specify a process default, and let the SAS values default to the process's default values.

arguments.name: MBF=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the number of I/O buffers you want OpenVMS RMS to allocate for a particular file. The value can range from 0 to 127 and represents the number of buffers used. By default, this option is set to a value of 2. If a value of 0 is specified, the default value for the process is used. The MBF= option (multibuffer count) is used for both input and output to control the number of buffers allocated for a particular file. If you want to control the number of buffers allocated for all the external files used during the SAS session, you can use the MBF= option in every FILE, FILENAME, or INFILE statement. The DCL SET RMS_DEFAULT command can be used to specify a process default. Then, you can let the SAS values default to the process's default values.

arguments.name: MESSAGE
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates the type of pipe. BYTE is the default value.

arguments.name: MISSOVER
arguments.description: Prevents an INPUT statement from reading a new input data record if it does not find values in the current input line for all the variables in the statement.

arguments.name: MOD
arguments.description: Indicates that data written to the file should be appended to the file

arguments.name: MVS
arguments.description: [type] For z/OS data sets.

arguments.name: N=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that are available to the input pointer at one time.

arguments.name: NBYTE=
arguments.description: Specifies the StatementOptionName of a variable that contains the number of bytes to read from a file when you are reading data in stream record format (RECFM=S in the FILENAME statement).

arguments.name: NEW
arguments.description: Indicates that a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, then it is deleted and re-created.

arguments.name: NOBLOCK
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates whether the client is to wait if no data is currently available. BLOCK is the default value.

arguments.name: NOEXPANDTABS
arguments.description: Specifies not to expand tab characters to the standard tab setting, which is set at 8-column intervals that start at column 9.

arguments.name: NOPAD
arguments.description: SAS does not pad the records that are read from an external file with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Specifies that the input file does not contain carriage-control characters.

arguments.name: NOTAB
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Instructs SAS to ignore tab characters between variables.

arguments.name: NRLS
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Specifies not to use record-level sharing (RLS) to open an RLS-eligible data set (INFILE only).

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.description: Use OBS= with FIRSTOBS= to read a range of records from the middle of a file.

arguments.name: <record-number>
arguments.description: Specifies the record number of the last record to read in an input file that is read sequentially.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of observations to process, which will be at least as large as the largest signed, 32-bit integer.

arguments.name: OLD
arguments.description: Indicates that a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, then the previous contents of the file are replaced.

arguments.name: PAD
arguments.description: SAS pads the records that are read from an external file with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: PASSWD=
arguments.description: Gives the appropriate password for a VSAM data set that has password protection.

arguments.name: PIPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unnamed pipe. Note: Some operating environments do not support pipes.

arguments.name: PLOTTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unbuffered graphics output device.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Specifies that the input file contains carriage-control characters.

arguments.name: PRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a printer or printer spool file.

arguments.name: RBA=
arguments.description: Specifies a numeric variable that you set to the relative byte address (RBA) of the data record that you want to read. The RBA= option indicates that addressed direct access is being used; it is appropriate for KSDS and ESDS. If you specify the CONTROLINTERVAL option, you can use the RBA= option to access control records in an RRDS (INFILE only).

arguments.name: RC4STOP
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Stops the DATA step from executing if a return code greater than 4 is returned by the operating environment when the VSAM data set is opened.

arguments.name: RECFM=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the record format of the external file.
arguments.help: RECFM=F | P | S | V|D | N | s370V | S370VB | S370VBS | STREAMLF

arguments.name: F
arguments.description: Fixed-record format

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: Print format.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: Stream-record format.

arguments.name: V
arguments.description: Variable-record format (the default)

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Indicates binary format and causes the file to be treated as a byte stream. If LRECL is not specified, by default SAS reads 256 bytes at a time from the file.

arguments.name: s370V
arguments.description: Indicates the variable S370 record format (V).

arguments.name: S370VB
arguments.description: Indicates the variable block S370 record format (VB).

arguments.name: S370VBS
arguments.description: Indicates the variable block with spanned records S370 record format (VBS).

arguments.name: STREAMLF
arguments.description: [For OpenVMS] Specifies StreamLF record format. Records are delimited by LF.

arguments.name: RECORDS=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that SAS sets to the number of logical records in a VSAM data set that has been opened for input.

arguments.name: RECORG=
arguments.description: [z/OS Host Option] Specifies the organization of records in a new VSAM data set. Use this option only if SMS is active.

arguments.name: KS
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM key-sequenced data set.

arguments.name: ES
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM entry-sequenced data set.

arguments.name: RR
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM relative-record data set.

arguments.name: LS
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM linear-space data set.

arguments.name: RESET
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Indicates that the VSAM file is reset to empty (no records) when it is opened. This option applies only to loading a VSAM data set that has been marked REUSE. You cannot use this option if the data set contains an alternate index.

arguments.name: RETRY=
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option]

arguments.name: RRN=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that you set to the relative record number (RRN) of the record that you want to read or write. This option indicates that keyed direct access is being used; it is appropriate for RRDS only.

arguments.name: SCANOVER
arguments.description: Causes the INPUT statement to scan the input data records until the character string that is specified in the @'character-string' expression is found.

arguments.name: SEQUENTIAL
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Specifies sequential VSAM record retrieval when either the RBA= (for an ESDS) or the RRN= option (for an RRDS) is specified (INFILE only).

arguments.name: SERVER
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option specifies the mode of a named pipe. The default value is SERVER.

arguments.name: SHAREBUFFERS
arguments.description: Specifies that the FILE statement and the INFILE statement share the same buffer.

arguments.name: SHR=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Overrides the default file-sharing attributes used for external files. With this option, you can indicate the access level you want to give other users. You can allow READ, WRITE, UPDATE, and DELETE access (as well as no access). By default with external files, files opened for input allow shared read access, and files opened for output or UPDATE do not allow shared access. However, you can allow other users to have READ and WRITE access to a file that you are opening for input only. To accomplish this, use the SHR= option. The syntax of the SHR= option is SHR=share-option-list where share-option-list can be one of the following: DEL specifies DELETE access. GET specifies shared READ access. NONE specifies no shared access. PUT specifies shared WRITE access. UPD specifies UPDATE access. You can combine these values in any order. For example, specifying the following indicates that you want shared DELETE, READ, and WRITE access:

arguments.name: SKIP
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Indicates skip-sequential processing of VSAM files. Skip-sequential processing finds the first record whose value is the same as the value specified by the KEY= option; records are read sequentially thereafter (INFILE only).

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable whose value SAS uses as the first column number of the record that the PUT _INFILE_ statement writes. Like automatic variables, the START variable is not written to the data set.

arguments.name: STOPOVER
arguments.description: Causes the DATA step to stop processing if an INPUT statement reaches the end of the current record without finding values for all variables in the statement.

arguments.name: TAPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a tape drive.

arguments.name: TEMP
arguments.description: [device-type] Creates a temporary file that exists only as long as the filename is assigned.

arguments.name: TERMINAL
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies the user's terminal.

arguments.name: TERMSTR=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the end-of-line character for the file. Use this option to share files between the UNIX and Windows operating environments.
arguments.help: TERMSTR=CR | CRLF | LF | NULL | NONE | NL | LFCR | CRNL

arguments.name: CR
arguments.description: Carriage return (CR).

arguments.name: CRLF
arguments.description: Carriage return (CR) followed by line feed (LF).

arguments.name: LF
arguments.description: Line feed only (the default).

arguments.name: NULL
arguments.description: NULL character (0x00).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Record terminators are not used. This parameter provides the same function as FILEDATA=BINARY.

arguments.name: NL
arguments.description: The newline character (x'15') is used as the record terminator. This parameter provides the same function as FILEDATA=TEXT.

arguments.name: LFCR
arguments.description: The sequence LF followed by CR is used as the record terminator.

arguments.name: CRNL
arguments.description: The sequence CR followed by NL is used as the record terminator.

arguments.name: TRUNCOVER
arguments.description: Overrides the default behavior of the INPUT statement when an input data record is shorter than the INPUT statement expects. By default, the INPUT statement automatically reads the next input data record. TRUNCOVER enables you to read variable-length records when some records are shorter than the INPUT statement expects. Variables without any values assigned are set to missing.

arguments.name: UNBUFFERED
arguments.description: Tells SAS not to perform a buffered ("look ahead") read.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric SAS variable that indicates that not every record that it reads is to be updated. Use this option when you are updating records in a VSAM data set (INFILE only). When an INFILE and a FILE statement reference the same VSAM data set, records are retrieved for update by default.

arguments.name: UPRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a Universal Printing printer definition StatementOptionName.

arguments.name: VSAM
arguments.description: [type] For VSAM files.

arguments.name: VTOC
arguments.description: [type] For a Volume Table of Contents (VTOC).

arguments.name: _INFILE_=
arguments.description: Specifies a character variable that references the contents of the current input buffer for this INFILE statement.

statements.name: INPUT
statements.description: Describes the arrangement of values in the input data record and assigns input values to the corresponding SAS variables.

statements.name: KEEP
statements.description: Specifies the variables to include in output SAS data sets.

statements.name: KILLTASK
statements.description: For asynchronous tasks, forces one or more active tasks or server sessions to terminate immediately.

statements.name: LEAVE
statements.description: Stops processing the current loop and resumes with the next statement in the sequence.

statements.name: LENGTH
statements.description: Specifies the number of bytes for storing variables.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Changes the default number of bytes that SAS uses to store the values of any newly created numeric variables.

statements.name: LINK
statements.description: Directs program execution immediately to the statement label that is specified and, if followed by a RETURN statement, returns execution to the statement that follows the LINK statement.

statements.name: LIST
statements.description: Writes to the SAS log the input data record for the observation that is being processed.

statements.name: LISTTASK
statements.description: Lists all active connections or tasks and identifies the execution status of each connection or task.

statements.name: LOCK
statements.description: Acquires and releases an exclusive lock on an existing SAS file.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: Releases a lock on the specified SAS file that was acquired by using the LOCK statement in your SAS session.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: Writes to the SAS log whether you have an exclusive lock on the specified SAS file.

statements.name: LOSTCARD
statements.description: Resynchronizes the input data when SAS encounters a missing or invalid record in data that has multiple records per observation.

statements.name: MERGE
statements.description: Joins observations from two or more SAS data sets into a single observation.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Names and creates a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.help: FIRSTOBS=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.help: OBS=n | nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX | MIN | MAX

statements.name: METHOD
statements.description: [This statement is valid only in DS2 and HPDS2 procedures.] Defines a block of code that can be called and executed multiple times.

arguments.name: BIGINT
arguments.description: Specifies an integer variable.

arguments.name: CHAR
arguments.description: Specifies a character variable.

arguments.name: DATE
arguments.description: Specifies a date variable.

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: Specifies a floating-point variable.

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: Specifies a floating-point variable.

arguments.name: FLOAT
arguments.description: Specifies a floating-point variable.

arguments.name: IDENTITY
arguments.description: Specifies an integer variable.

arguments.name: INIT
arguments.description: Without Arguments The METHOD INIT statement has no arguments. If you try to pass arguments, an error will occur. Details: Typically, the INIT method will contain any initialization code such as variable initialization or opening of tables. Code in the INIT method will run once at the beginning of the TSPL program. Before the INIT method has run, variables in the program data vector which have not been retained '(by using the RETAIN statement) will be set to either SAS missing values or null values depending on whether you are in SAS mode or ANSI mode.

arguments.name: INT
arguments.description: Specifies an integer variable.

arguments.name: NCHAR
arguments.description: Specifies a character variable.

arguments.name: NVARCHAR
arguments.description: Specifies a character variable.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: Specifies a floating-point variable.

arguments.name: RETURNS
arguments.description: Specifies the data type of the value that the method returns. The type can be any valid character, numeric, or date type.

arguments.name: RUN
arguments.description: Without Arguments: The METHOD RUN statement has no arguments. If you try to pass arguments, an error will occur. Details: Typically, the RUN method will contain the main TSPL program code. The RUN method has the same feature of automatic, implicit looping as the Base SAS DATA step. After the RUN method has been executed one time, the RUN method either runs again or control is passed to the TERM method.

arguments.name: SMALLINT
arguments.description: Specifies an integer variable.

arguments.name: TERM
arguments.description: Without Arguments: The METHOD TERM statement has no arguments. If you try to pass arguments, an error will occur. Details: Typically, the TERM method will contain any finalization code such as writing data to the SAS log. Code in the TERM method will run once at the end of the TSPL program.

arguments.name: TIME
arguments.description: Specifies a time variable. precision specifies the precision for a TIME data type.

arguments.name: TIMESTAMP
arguments.description: Specifies both a date and time variable. precision specifies the precision for a TIMESTAMP data type.

arguments.name: TINYINT
arguments.description: Specifies an integer variable.

arguments.name: VARBINARY
arguments.description: Specifies a varying-length binary variable. Alias: BINARY VARYING

arguments.name: VARCHAR
arguments.description: Specifies a character variable.

statements.name: MISSING
statements.description: Assigns characters in your input data to represent special missing values for numeric data.

arguments.name: CUREOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a variable that contains the observation number that was just read from the data set.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator.

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: Specifies a simple or composite index of the SAS data file that is being modified. The KEY= argument retrieves observations from that SAS data file based on index values that are supplied by like-named variables in another source of information.

arguments.name: KEYRESET=
arguments.description: Controls whether a KEY= search should begin at the top of the index for the data set that is being read. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 1, the index lookup begins at the top of the index. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 0, the index lookup is not reset and the lookup continues where the prior lookup ended.

arguments.name: NOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable whose value is usually the total number of observations in the input data set. For certain SAS views, SAS cannot determine the number of observations. In these cases, SAS sets the value of the NOBS= variable to the largest positive integer value available in the operating environment.

arguments.name: POINT=
arguments.description: Reads SAS data sets using random (direct) access by observation number. variable names a variable whose value is the number of the observation to read. The POINT= variable is available anywhere in the DATA step, but it is not added to any SAS data set.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: Causes a KEY= search always to begin at the top of the index for the data file being modified.

arguments.name: UPDATEMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether missing variable values in a transaction data set are to be allowed to replace existing variable values in a master data set.

arguments.name: MISSINGCHECK
arguments.description: Prevents missing variable values in a transaction data set from replacing values in a master data set.

arguments.name: NOMISSINGCHECK
arguments.description: Allows missing variable values in a transaction data set to replace values in a master data set by preventing the check from being performed.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: CATALOG=
arguments.description: By default, no value is assigned to CATALOG=, which means that temporary GRSEGs are not copied to a permanent catalog.

arguments.name: <permanent-catalog>
arguments.description: Copies any temporary GRSEG to the specified permanent catalog and keeps a reference to the permanent GRSEG in the document. This value persists until the ODS DOCUMENT statement is closed, or until you delete it by specifying CATALOG=_NULL_. The permanent catalog has the following form: <libref.><member-name>;

arguments.name: _NULL_
arguments.description: Deletes the catalog name that was previously specified for the CATALOG= option. Thereafter, temporary GRSEGs are not copied into the permanent catalog, and thus are unavailable in subsequent sessions.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: DIR=
arguments.description: Specifies the directory path and/or label for ODS output. LABEL=label assigns a label to a path. PATH= path <(access-option)> is specified as a sequence of entries that are delimited by backslashes. path can have the form: path<#sequence-number> where path is the name of the path. #sequence-number is a number which, when combined with a pathname, uniquely identifies the entry in the directory that contains it. access-option specifies the access mode for the ODS document. WRITE -- opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes one or more output objects from the DOCUMENT destination.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Assigns a label to a path.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Syntax: NAME= <libref.>member-name<(access-option)> where: libref specifies the SAS library where the document is stored. Default: If no library name is specified, the WORK library is used. member-name specifies the document name. access-option specifies the access mode for the ODS document. WRITE opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Is specified as a sequence of entries that are delimited by backslashes.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects one or more output objects for the DOCUMENT destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: UPDATE
arguments.description: [access-option] Opens an ODS document and appends new content to the document. UPDATE provides update access as well as read access.

arguments.name: WRITE
arguments.description: [access-option] Opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

statements.name: ODS ESCAPECHAR=
statements.description: escape-character specifies the special character that identifies the inline formatting symbol. The escape-character should be one of the following rarely used characters: @, ^, or \.

statements.name: ODS EXCLUDE
statements.description: Specifies output objects to exclude from ODS destinations. Each exclusion has the following form: output-object <(PERSIST)> output-object specifies one or more output objects to exclude.
