To specify an output object, you need to know which output objects your SAS program produces. The ODS TRACE statement writes to the SAS log a trace record that includes the path, the label, and other information about each output object that is produced. (PERSIST) keeps the output-object that precedes the PERSIST option in the exclusion list, even until you \ explicitly modify the list with any of the following ODS statements: o any ODS SELECT statement o ODS EXCLUDE NONE o ODS EXCLUDE ALL o an ODS EXCLUDE statement that applies to the same output object but does not specify PERSIST This action is true even if the DATA or procedure step ends. Requirement: You must enclose PERSIST in parentheses.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS does not send any output objects to the open destination. Alias: ODS EXCLUDE DEFAULT Interaction: If you specify ALL without specifying a destination, ODS sets the overall list to EXCLUDE ALL and sets all other lists to their defaults. Tip: Using ODS EXCLUDE ALL is different from closing a destination. The destination remains open, but no output objects are sent to it.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS send all of the output objects to the open destination. Interaction: If you specify the NONE argument without specifying a destination, ODS sets the overall list to EXCLUDE NONE and sets all other lists to their defaults. Tip: ODS EXCLUDE NONE has the same effect as ODS SELECT ALL.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: Suppresses the warning that an output object was requested but not created.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: Excludes output objects that meet a particular condition. For example, the following statement excludes only output objects with the word "Histogram" in their name: ods exclude where=(_name_ ? 'Histogram'); where-expression is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators and operands. where-expression has this form: (subsetting-variable <comparison-operator where-expression-n>) subsetting-variable Subsetting variables are a special kind of WHERE expression operand used by SAS to help you find common values in items. For example, this EXCLUDE statement excludes only output objects with the path City_Pop_90.TestsForLocation : ods exclude / where=(_path_ = 'City_Pop_90.TestsForLocation' ); subsetting-variable is one of the following:

statements.name: ODS GRAPHICS
statements.description: Enables or disables ODS graphics processing and sets graphics environment options. This statement affects ODS template-based graphics only. The ODS GRAPHICS statement does not affect device-based graphics.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables ODS Graphics processing.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables ODS Graphics processing. This is the default if no argument is used.

arguments.name: ANTIALIAS
arguments.description: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.

arguments.name: ANTIALIASMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of markers or lines to be anti-aliased before anti-aliasing is disabled. Default: 1000

arguments.name: BORDER
arguments.description: Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: BORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Specifies not to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Specifies to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: DISCRETEMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of discrete values to be shown in any graph. Default: 1000

arguments.name: GROUPMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of group values to be shown in any graph. Any graph that supports the GROUP= option is affected. Default: 1000

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of any graph.

arguments.name: IMAGEFMT=
arguments.description: Specifies the image format to be used. If the image format is not valid for the active output destination, the format is automatically changed to the default image format for that destination.
arguments.help: IMAGEFMT=BMP | DIB | EMF | EPSI | GIF | JFIF | JPEG | PBM | PDF | PNG | PS | SASEMF | TIFF | WMF | STATIC

arguments.name: BMP
arguments.description: Microsoft Windows Device Independent Bitmap

arguments.name: DIB
arguments.description: Microsoft Windows Device Independent Bitmap

arguments.name: EMF
arguments.description: Microsoft NT Enhanced Metafile

arguments.name: EPSI
arguments.description: Microsoft NT Enhanced Metafile

arguments.name: GIF
arguments.description: Graphics Interchange Format

arguments.name: JFIF
arguments.description: JPEG File Interchange Format

arguments.name: JPEG
arguments.description: Joint Photographic Experts Group

arguments.name: PBM
arguments.description: Portable Bitmap Utilities

arguments.name: PDF
arguments.description: Portable Document Format

arguments.name: PNG
arguments.description: Portable Network Graphic

arguments.name: PS
arguments.description: PostScript Image File Format

arguments.name: SASEMF
arguments.description: Enhanced Metafile

arguments.name: TIFF
arguments.description: Tagged Image File Format

arguments.name: WMF
arguments.description: Microsoft Windows Metafile

arguments.name: STATIC
arguments.description: Uses the best quality static image format for the active output destination. This is the default.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP
arguments.description: Specifies to generate data tips.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP=
arguments.description: Specifies to generate data tips.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate data tips.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Specifies to generate data tips.

arguments.name: IMAGENAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the base image filename.

arguments.name: LABELMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of labeled areas before labeling is disabled.

arguments.name: MAXLEGENDAREA=
arguments.description: Specifies an integer that is interpreted as the maximum percentage of the overall graphics area that a legend can occupy. Default: 20

arguments.name: NOANTIALIAS
arguments.description: Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.

arguments.name: NOBORDER
arguments.description: Specifies not to draw a border around any graph.

arguments.name: NOIMAGEMAP
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate data tips.

arguments.name: NOSCALE
arguments.description: Does not scale the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: PANELCELLMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of cells in a graph panel where the number of cells is determined dynamically by classification variables. Default: 10000

arguments.name: RESET
arguments.description: Resets all of the options to their defaults.

arguments.name: RESET=
arguments.description: Resets the specified option to its default value.
arguments.help: RESET=ALL | ANTIALIAS | ANTIALIASMAX | BORDER | INDEX | HEIGHT | IMAGEMAP | LABELMAX | SCALE | TIPMAX | WIDTH

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Resets all of the reset-options to their defaults.

arguments.name: ANTIALIAS
arguments.description: Resets the ANTIALIAS option to its default.

arguments.name: ANTIALIASMAX
arguments.description: Resets the ANTIALIASMAX option to its default.

arguments.name: BORDER
arguments.description: Resets the BORDER= option to its default.

arguments.name: INDEX
arguments.description: Resets the index counter that is appended to static image files.

arguments.name: HEIGHT
arguments.description: Resets the HEIGHT= option to its default.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP
arguments.description: Resets the IMAGEMAP= option to its default.

arguments.name: LABELMAX
arguments.description: Resets the LABELMAX= option to its default.

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Resets the SCALE= option to its default.

arguments.name: TIPMAX
arguments.description: Resets the TIPMAX= option to its default.

arguments.name: WIDTH
arguments.description: Resets the WIDTH= option to its default.

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Scales the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of any graph. Requires a nonnegative number.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Does not scale the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Scales the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: TIPMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of distinct mouse-over areas allowed before data tips are disabled. Default: 500

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of any graph. Requires a nonnegative number.

statements.name: ODS LISTING
statements.help: ODS LISTING <EXCLUDE/SELECT ALL><CLOSE><EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE> ...

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Excludes/Selects all output objects for the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the LISTING destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: DATAPANEL=
arguments.description: Suggests how to split a table that is too wide to fit on a single page into sections of columns and rows. Each section of columns and rows is a data panel. Each data panel has column headings at the top.

arguments.name: <number>
arguments.description: Writes the specified number of observations in a panel, if possible. More than one panel can occur on every page if space permits. Range: 1 to the largest integer that the operating system supports.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Bases the size of the panel on the way that the table is stored in memory. This value provides the fastest performance. However, if the table contains many columns, the number of rows in each panel might be small.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Tries to make panels that match the page size. If the table contains more columns than can fit on a page, the first page is filled with as many observations as possible for as many columns as can fit on a single line. The second page contains the same observations for the next group of columns, and so on, until all rows and columns have been printed.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each open output destination.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes one or more output objects from the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the file to write to. file-specification is one of the following: 'external-file' is the name of an external file to which to write.

arguments.name: GPATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. file-specification specifies the file or SAS catalog to which to write. file-specification is one of the following: external-file is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. libref.catalog specifies a SAS catalog to which to write. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE specifies a URL for file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file. Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution of ODS graphics output. Output from device-based graphics is not affected. Default: 100

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Excludes/Selects no output objects for the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects output objects for the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: SGE=
arguments.description: Determines whether you can edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Turns on the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Turns off the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: Specifies a URL for file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file. Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specifies a unique base name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current body file.

arguments.name: ARCHIVE=
arguments.description: The ARCHIVE= option is only valid for the GOPTIONS Java device. The ARCHIVE= option allows you to specify a string to identify which applet to use in order to view the ODS HTML output.

arguments.name: ATTRIBUTES=
arguments.description: Writes the specified attributes between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: Specifies the text to use as the first part of all links and references that ODS creates in the output files.

arguments.name: BODY=
arguments.description: Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains the primary output that is created by the ODS statement.

arguments.name: CHARSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the character set to be generated in the META declaration for the HTML output.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: CODE=
arguments.description: Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains relevant style information, such as XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language).

arguments.name: CODEBASE=
arguments.description: Creates a file path that is used by the GOPTIONS devices.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a table of contents for the output. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each open output destination.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

arguments.name: 'warabic'
arguments.description: Arabic

arguments.name: 'wbaltic'
arguments.description: Baltic

arguments.name: 'wlatin2'
arguments.description: Central Europe

arguments.name: 'wcyrillic'
arguments.description: Cyrillic

arguments.name: 'wgreek'
arguments.description: Greek

arguments.name: 'whebrew'
arguments.description: Hebrew

arguments.name: 'wturkish'
arguments.description: Turkish

arguments.name: 'wvietnamese'
arguments.description: Vietnamese

arguments.name: 'wlatin1'
arguments.description: Western

arguments.name: 'utf-8'
arguments.description: Unicode encoding

arguments.name: 'ms-950'
arguments.description: Traditional Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-936'
arguments.description: Simplified Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-932'
arguments.description: Japanese

arguments.name: 'ms-949'
arguments.description: Korean

arguments.name: EVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies an event and the value for event variables that are associated with the event.
arguments.help: EVENT=FILE= | FINISH | LABEL= | NAME | START | STYLE= | TARGET= | TEXT= | URL=

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes one or more output objects from the destination.

arguments.name: FRAME=
arguments.description: Opens a MARKUP family destination and, for HTML output, specifies the file that integrates the table of contents, the page contents, and the body file.

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the SGSCATTER procedure. The footnotes appear inside the graph borders. If you open the frame file, then you see a table of contents, a table of pages, or both, as well as the body file. For XLM output, FRAME= specifies the file that contains the DTD. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: GPATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. 'aggregate-file-storage-location' specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set. Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator -- is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file. Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: Prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the SGSCATTER procedure. The title appears inside the graph borders.

arguments.name: HEADTEXT=
arguments.description: where: markup-document-head specifies the markup tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 100. Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.

arguments.name: METATEXT=
arguments.description: where: 'metatext-for-document-head' specifies the HTML code that provides the browser with information about the document that it is loading. For example, this attribute could specify the content type and the character set to use.

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Creates a new body file at the specified starting-point.

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each output object.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each page of output.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: Prints the title that is created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: OPTIONS
arguments.description: Specifies tagset-specific suboptions and a named value. (DOC='QUICK' | 'HELP' | 'SETTINGS') provides information about the specified tagset. QUICK describes the options available for this tagset. HELP provides generic help and information with a quick reference. SETTINGS provides the current option settings. suboption(s) specifies one or more suboptions that are valid for the specified tagset. Suboptions have the following format:

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.

arguments.name: PAGE=
arguments.description: Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a description of each page of the body file, and contains links to the body file. ODS produces a new page of output whenever a procedure requests a new page. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog.

arguments.name: PARAMETERS=
arguments.description: Writes the specified parameters between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output. parameter-pair specifies the name and value of each parameter. parameter-pair has the following form: 'parameter-name'= 'parameter-value' where: parameter-name -- is the name of the parameter.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the "aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref. 'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set. Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from PATH= when it constructs links. libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

arguments.name: RECORD_SEPARATOR=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files. Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment. alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x Operating Environment Information: In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects one or more output objects for the specified destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the style definition to use in writing the output files.

arguments.name: STYLESHEET=
arguments.description: Opens a markup family destination and places the style information for markup output into an external file, or reads style sheet information from an existing file. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog. See the discussion of the PATH= option.

arguments.name: TAGSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a keyword value for a tagset. A tagset is a template that defines how to create an output type from a SAS format.
arguments.help: TAGSET=CHTML | CORE | CSV | CSVALL | CSVBYLINE | DEFAULT | DOCBOOK | ExcelXP | HTML4 | HTMLCSS | HTMLPANEL | IMODE | MSOFFICE2K | MVSHTML | PHTML | PYX | RTF | SASREPORT | WML | WMLOLIST | XHTML | EVENT_MAP | NAMEDHTML | SHORT_MAP | STYLE_DISPLAY | STYLE_POPUP | TEXT_MAP | TPL_STYLE_LIST | TPL_STYLE_MAP

arguments.name: CHTML
arguments.description: Produces compact, minimal HTML output that does not use style information.

arguments.name: CORE
arguments.description: Contains a table of Unicode values and mnemonics.

arguments.name: CSV
arguments.description: Produces tabular output that contains columns of data values that are separated by commas.

arguments.name: CSVALL
arguments.description: Produces tabular output with titles that contain columns of data values that are separated by commas.

arguments.name: CSVBYLINE
arguments.description: Produces output with comma-separated values and columns of data that are separated by commas.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: Produces XML output.

arguments.name: DOCBOOK
arguments.description: Produces XML output that conforms to the DocBook DTD by OASIS.

arguments.name: ExcelXP
arguments.description: Produces Microsoft's spreadsheetML XML. This tagset is used to import data into XML.

arguments.name: HTML4
arguments.description: Produces HTML 4.0 embedded style sheets.

arguments.name: HTMLCSS
arguments.description: produces HTML output with cascading style sheets that is similar to ODS HTML output.

arguments.name: HTMLPANEL
arguments.description: Creates panels for By-grouped graphs.

arguments.name: IMODE
arguments.description: produces HTML output as a column of output that is separated by lines.

arguments.name: MSOFFICE2K
arguments.description: Produces HTML code for output generated by ODS for Microsoft Office products.

arguments.name: MVSHTML
arguments.description: Produces URLs within HTML files that are used in the z/OS operating environment.

arguments.name: PHTML
arguments.description: Produces simple HTML output that uses twelve style elements and no class attributes.

arguments.name: PYX
arguments.description: Produces PYX, which is a simple, line-oriented notation used by Pyxie to describe the information communicated by an XML parser to an XML application.

arguments.name: RTF
arguments.description: Produces measured RTF.

arguments.name: SASREPORT
arguments.description: Causes imbedded data to be produced in CSV format.

arguments.name: WML
arguments.description: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with a list of URLs as a table of contents.

arguments.name: WMLOLIST
arguments.description: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with an option list for the table of contents.

arguments.name: XHTML
arguments.description: Produces output in HTML format.

arguments.name: EVENT_MAP
arguments.description: Creates XML output that shows which events are being triggered and which variables are used by an event to send output from a SAS process to an output file.

arguments.name: NAMEDHTML
arguments.description: Creates HTML output similar to STYLE_POPUP, but with all the objects labeled as they are when using ODS TRACE.

arguments.name: SHORT_MAP
arguments.description: Creates a subset of the XML output that is created by the EVENT_MAP tagset.

arguments.name: STYLE_DISPLAY
arguments.description: Creates a sample page of HTML output that is similar to STYLE_POPUP output.

arguments.name: STYLE_POPUP
arguments.description: Creates HTML like HTMLCSS, but if you're using Internet Explorer, STYLE_POPUP displays a window that shows the resolved ODS style definition for any item that you select.

arguments.name: TEXT_MAP
arguments.description: Creates text output that shows which events are being triggered as ODS handles the output objects.

arguments.name: TPL_STYLE_LIST
arguments.description: Creates HTML output in a bulleted list similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

arguments.name: TPL_STYLE_MAP
arguments.description: Creates XML output similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Inserts text into your document by triggering the paragraph event and specifying a text string to be assigned to the VALUE event variable.

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

statements.name: ODS NOPROCTITLE
statements.description: Suppresses the writing of the title of the procedure that produces the results.

statements.name: ODS NOUSEGOPT
statements.description: Specifies that ODS not use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: Sets the list for the OUTPUT destination to EXCLUDE ALL.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the OUTPUT destination. When an ODS destination is closed, ODS does not send output to that destination. Closing a destination frees some system resources.

arguments.name: MATCH_ALL=
arguments.description: Creates a new data set for each output object.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: Suppresses the warning that an output object was requested but not created.

arguments.name: PERSIST=
arguments.description: Determines when ODS closes any data sets that it is creating, and determines when ODS removes output objects from the selection list for the OUTPUT destination.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Maintains the list of definitions even after the procedure ends, until you explicitly modify it.

arguments.name: RUN
arguments.description: Maintains the list of definitions and keeps open the data sets that it is creating even if the procedure or DATA step ends, or until you explicitly modify the list.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes to the SAS log the current selection or exclusion list for the OUTPUT destination. If the list is the default list (EXCLUDE ALL), then SHOW also writes the current overall selection or exclusion list.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the root name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current file.

arguments.name: AUTHOR=
arguments.description: Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the author.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: base-text is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file. Consider this specification:

arguments.name: BOOKMARKGEN
arguments.description: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: BOOKMARKGEN=
arguments.description: Controls the generation of bookmarks in a PDF file.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: BOOKMARKLIST=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to generate and display the list of bookmarks for a PDF file.

arguments.name: HIDE
arguments.description: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are not automatically displayed when you open the PDF file.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate a list of bookmarks for your PDF file.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are automatically displayed when you open the PDF file.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: Applies the specified color scheme to your output.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: Creates full color output for both text and graphics.

arguments.name: GRAY
arguments.description: Creates gray scale output for both text and graphics.

arguments.name: MONO
arguments.description: Creates monochromatic output for both text and graphics.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Does not use all the color information that the style definition provides.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Uses all the color information that a style definition provides, including background color.

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. n is the number columns per page.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: Controls the compression of a PDF file. Compression reduces the size of the file. n specifies the level of compression. The larger the number, the greater the compression. For example, n=0 is completely uncompressed, and n=9 is the maximum compression level.

arguments.name: CONTENTS
arguments.description: Generates a printable table of contents page.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Controls the generation of a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Does not generate a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Generates a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: CSSSTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. file-specification specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. file-specification is one of the following: "external-file" is the name of the external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. "URL" is a URL to an external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks.

arguments.name: DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution for output files. Default: 150 Restriction: The DPI= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes output objects from the destination.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the file that contains the output. external-file is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks.

arguments.name: HOST
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS use the printer drivers that the host system provides. Interaction: In an ODS printer family statement that refers to an open ODS PRINTER destination, the HOST option forces ODS to close the destination and all files that are associated with it, and to open a new instance of the destination.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: Enables you to open multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: KEYWORDS=
arguments.description: Inserts into the output file's metadata, a string of keywords. Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. Restriction: The KEYWORDS= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Writes all output to the file that is currently open.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Starts a new file for each output object. For SAS/GRAPH this means that ODS creates a new file for each SAS/GRAPH output file that the program generates.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Starts a new file for each page of output. A page break occurs when a procedure explicitly starts a new page (not because the page size was exceeded) or when you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Starts a body file each time that you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: NOBOOKMARKGEN
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: NOCONTENTS
arguments.description: Does not generate a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: NOPDFNOTE
arguments.description: Modifies the behavior of PDFMARK so that notes are not added to the file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

arguments.name: NOTOC
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS omit the table of contents (Bookmark list) that is produced by default when producing PDF or PDFMARK output.

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. package-name specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

arguments.name: PCL
arguments.description: Creates PCL output. Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PDF or PS option.

arguments.name: PDF
arguments.description: Creates PDF output. Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PCL or PS option.

arguments.name: PDFMARK
arguments.description: Enables ODS to insert special tags into a PostScript file. When you use software such as Adobe Acrobat (not Adobe Viewer), Acrobat Distiller interprets the tags to create a PDF file that contains the following items: o bookmarks for each section of the output and for each table. o references for items that are associated with the URL= style attribute. o notes for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute. Notes are optional, and are based on the PDFNOTE option.

arguments.name: PDFNOTE
arguments.description: Adds notes to a PDF file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

arguments.name: PDFTOC=
arguments.description: Controls the level of the expansion of the table of contents in PDF documents.

arguments.name: PRINTER=
arguments.description: Creates output that is formatted for the specified printer. Default: If you do not specify a printer, then ODS formats the printer output for the printer that is specified by one of two SAS system options: o SYSPRINT= if you are using the Windows operating environment and do not specify any of the following options: PCL, PDFMARK, POSTSCRIPT, PS, or SAS.

arguments.name: PS
arguments.description: Creates PostScript output.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects output objects for the specified destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STARTPAGE=
arguments.description: Controls page breaks.

arguments.name: NEVER
arguments.description: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.

arguments.name: NOW
arguments.description: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested by the procedure code.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the style definition to use in writing the printer output.

arguments.name: SUBJECT=
arguments.description: Inserts into the metadata of a file the text string that you specify as the subject. subject-text is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the subject. Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. Restriction: The SUBJECT= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Inserts a text string into your output. Requirement: You must enclose text-string in quotation marks.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the title. Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. Restriction: The TITLE= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: For multiple page tables, ensures uniformity from page to page within a single table. When the UNIFORM option is in effect, ODS reads the entire table before it starts to print it so that it can determine the column widths that are necessary to accommodate all the data. These column widths are applied to all pages of a multiple page table.

statements.name: ODS PROCLABEL
statements.description: where: 'string' is the procedure label that you specify.

statements.name: ODS PROCTITLE
statements.description: Writes, in the output, the name of the procedure that produces the results.

statements.name: ODS RESULTS
statements.description: Tracks ODS output in the Results window.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Turns off the tracking of output that ODS generates in the Results window.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Tracks output that ODS generates in the Results window.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the base name for the RTF anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current file.

arguments.name: AUTHOR=
arguments.description: Inserts the text string that you specify as the author into the metadata of a file.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: base-text is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file. Consider this specification:

arguments.name: BODYTITLE
arguments.description: Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the RTF document instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document.

arguments.name: BODYTITLE_AUX
arguments.description: Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes be placed into the body of the RTF document instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document. These titles and footnotes are put into cells, which allows titles and footnotes to be centered, left-justified, or right-justified.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the RTF destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. Default: the number of one-inch columns that fit on the page.

arguments.name: <n>
arguments.description: Is the number of one-inch columns that you want on the page.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of one-inch-wide columns for the paper size and margin setting. This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation.

arguments.name: CONTENTS
arguments.description: Produces a table of contents page for RTF documents that are opened in Microsoft Word. The table of contents page contains a Table of Contents field, which puts all of the contents information that is embedded in the document into a table of contents. To expand the table of contents, right-click under the title in Microsoft Word and select Update Field from the selection list.

arguments.name: CSSSTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. file-specification specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. file-specification is one of the following: "external-file" is the name of the external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. "URL" is a URL to an external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each open output destination.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

arguments.name: 'warabic'
arguments.description: Arabic

arguments.name: 'wbaltic'
arguments.description: Baltic

arguments.name: 'wlatin2'
arguments.description: Central Europe

arguments.name: 'wcyrillic'
arguments.description: Cyrillic

arguments.name: 'wgreek'
arguments.description: Greek

arguments.name: 'whebrew'
arguments.description: Hebrew

arguments.name: 'wturkish'
arguments.description: Turkish

arguments.name: 'wvietnamese'
arguments.description: Vietnamese

arguments.description: Western

arguments.name: 'utf-8'
arguments.description: Unicode encoding

arguments.name: 'ms-950'
arguments.description: Traditional Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-936'
arguments.description: Simplified Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-932'
arguments.description: Japanese

arguments.name: 'ms-949'
arguments.description: Korean

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes output objects from the RTF destination.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: 'external-file' is the name of an external file to which to write.

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Includes all of the currently defined footnotes within the graphics output.

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: Includes all of the currently defined titles within the graphics output that is called by the body file.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 200. Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.

arguments.name: KEEPN
arguments.description: ODS allows table splits only if the entire table cannot fit on one page.

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each output object.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each page of output.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Prevents all of the currently defined footnotes from appearing in the graphics file. Instead, they become part of the RTF file.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: Prevents all of the currently defined titles from appearing in the graphics output. Instead, the titles become part of the RTF file.

arguments.name: NOKEEPN
arguments.description: ODS lets a table split at a page break.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: NOTOC_DATA
arguments.description: Instructs ODS not to insert contents data into the RTF file.

arguments.name: OPERATOR=
arguments.description: Inserts the text you specify into the metadata of the RTF file.

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. package-name specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the "aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref. 'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set. Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from PATH= when it constructs links. libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

arguments.name: RECORD_SEPARATOR=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files. Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment. alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x Operating Environment Information: In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: SASDATE
arguments.description: Writes to the RTF file the time and the date that you started your SAS session.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects output objects for the RTF destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STARTPAGE=
arguments.description: Controls page breaks.

arguments.name: NEVER
arguments.description: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.

arguments.name: NOW
arguments.description: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested by the procedure code.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the style definition for ODS to use to write the RTF files.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Inserts text into your RTF output. Restriction: You cannot use both the NEWFILE= and TEXT= options in the same ODS RTF statement. You must use a separate ODS RTF statement for each of these options.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: Inserts the text string that you specify as the title into the metadata of a file. title-text is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the title.

arguments.name: TOC_DATA
arguments.description: Instructs ODS to insert contents data into the RTF file.

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

statements.name: ODS SELECT
statements.description: Specifies output objects for ODS destinations. Each selection has the following form: output-object <(PERSIST)> output-object specifies the output object to select. To specify an output object, you need to know which output objects your SAS program produces. The ODS TRACE statement writes to the SAS log a trace record that includes the path, the label, and other information about each output object that your SAS program produces. (PERSIST) keeps the output-object that precedes the PERSIST option in the selection list, even if the DATA or procedure step ends, until you explicitly modify the list with one of the following: o any ODS EXCLUDE statement o ODS SELECT NONE o ODS SELECT ALL o an ODS SELECT statement that applies to the same output object but does not specify PERSIST Requirement: You must enclose PERSIST in parentheses.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS send all of the output objects to the open destination. Alias: ODS SELECT DEFAULT

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS does not send any output objects to the open destination. Interaction: If you specify NONE and you do not specify a destination, ODS sets the overall list to SELECT NONE and sets all other lists to their defaults. Tip: Using the NONE action is different from closing a destination. The output destination is still open, but ODS restricts the output that it sends to the destination.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: Suppresses the warning that an output object was requested but not created.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: Selects output objects that meet a particular condition. For example, the following statement selects only output objects with the word "Histogram" in their name: ods select where=(_name_ ? 'Histogram'); where-expression is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators and operands. where-expression has this form: (subsetting-variable <comparison-operator where-expression-n>) subsetting-variable Subsetting variables are a special kind of WHERE expression operand used by SAS to help you find common values in items. For example, this ODS SELECT statement selects only output objects with the path City_Pop_90.TestsForLocation : ods select / where=(_path_ = 'City_Pop_90.TestsForLocation' ); subsetting-variable is one of the following:

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the base name for the RTF anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current file.

arguments.name: AUTHOR=
arguments.description: Inserts the text string that you specify as the author into the metadata of a file.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: base-text is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file. Consider this specification:

arguments.name: BODYTITLE
arguments.description: Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the RTF document instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document.

arguments.name: BODYTITLE_AUX
arguments.description: Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes be placed into the body of the RTF document instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document. These titles and footnotes are put into cells, which allows titles and footnotes to be centered, left-justified, or right-justified.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the RTF destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. Default: the number of one-inch columns that fit on the page.

arguments.name: <n>
arguments.description: Is the number of one-inch columns that you want on the page.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of one-inch-wide columns for the paper size and margin setting. This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation.

arguments.name: CONTENTS
arguments.description: Produces a table of contents page for RTF documents that are opened in Microsoft Word. The table of contents page contains a Table of Contents field, which puts all of the contents information that is embedded in the document into a table of contents. To expand the table of contents, right-click under the title in Microsoft Word and select Update Field from the selection list.

arguments.name: CSSSTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. file-specification specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. file-specification is one of the following: "external-file" is the name of the external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. "URL" is a URL to an external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each open output destination.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.
