arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes output objects from the RTF destination.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: 'external-file' is the name of an external file to which to write.

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Includes all of the currently defined footnotes within the graphics output.

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: Includes all of the currently defined titles within the graphics output that is called by the body file.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 200. Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.

arguments.name: KEEPN
arguments.description: ODS allows table splits only if the entire table cannot fit on one page.

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each output object.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each page of output.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Prevents all of the currently defined footnotes from appearing in the graphics file. Instead, they become part of the RTF file.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: Prevents all of the currently defined titles from appearing in the graphics output. Instead, the titles become part of the RTF file.

arguments.name: NOKEEPN
arguments.description: ODS lets a table split at a page break.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: NOTOC_DATA
arguments.description: Instructs ODS not to insert contents data into the RTF file.

arguments.name: OPERATOR=
arguments.description: Inserts the text you specify into the metadata of the RTF file.

arguments.name: OPTIONS
arguments.description: Specifies ODS TAGSETS.RTF specific suboptions and a named value. (CONTENTS= 'YES') produces a table of contents (TOC) page for RTF documents that are opened in Microsoft Word. (DOC='QUICK' | 'HELP' | 'SETTINGS') provides information about the tagset. (SECT='rtf_control_string' | 'OFF' | 'NONE') inserts RTF control words into the section data specifications. TABLES_OFF='style_elements' | 'STYLE_ELEMENTS' | 'OFF' ) determines whether tables will be used. (TOC_DATA ='ON' | 'OFF') specifies whether to show the contents data in the RTF file. (TROWD='rtf_control_string' | ' OFF') inserts raw RTF specifications directly into header descriptions of the table row. (TRHDR='rtf_control_string' | 'OFF')

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. package-name specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

arguments.name: PAGEPANELS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of panels permitted per page before ODS inserts a page break.

arguments.name: <n>
arguments.description: Specifies a positive integer. Replace n with an actual value.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that paneling will be handled the way that it has always been handled by traditional ODS RTF. That is, all of the first panel is written, then all of the second panel, and so on, until all of the table information is written.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the "aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref. 'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set. Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from PATH= when it constructs links. libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

arguments.name: RECORD_SEPARATOR=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files. Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment. alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x Operating Environment Information: In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: SASDATE
arguments.description: Writes to the RTF file the time and the date that you started your SAS session.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects output objects for the RTF destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STARTPAGE=
arguments.description: Controls page breaks.

arguments.name: NEVER
arguments.description: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.

arguments.name: NOW
arguments.description: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested by the procedure code.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the style definition for ODS to use to write the RTF files.

arguments.name: TABLEROWS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows in each table before ODS inserts a page break. If the table is narrow enough to fit on a page, n lines will be written to the table before a page break. If the table is too wide for a page, the page is broken into panels. In each panel, n rows will be written. When all the panels for n rows have been written, a page break is inserted before the next group of panels is written.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Inserts text into your RTF output. Restriction: You cannot use both the NEWFILE= and TEXT= options in the same ODS RTF statement. You must use a separate ODS RTF statement for each of these options.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: Inserts the text string that you specify as the title into the metadata of a file. title-text is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the title.

arguments.name: TOC_DATA
arguments.description: Instructs ODS to insert contents data into the RTF file.

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: Ensures uniformity from page to page within a single table that requires multiple pages.

statements.name: ODS TEXT=
statements.description: where: text-string specifies the text to insert into your output. This text is sent to all open supported output destinations. Restriction: The ODS TEXT= statement does not support the OUTPUT destination or the LISTING destination. All other ODS destinations are supported. Requirement: You must enclose 'text-string' in parentheses. Tip: The UserText style element controls text specified with the TEXT= statement.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Turns off the writing of the trace record.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Turns on the writing of the trace record.

arguments.name: EXCLUDED
arguments.description: Includes, in the trace record, information for excluded output objects.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: Includes the label path for the output object in the record. You can use a label path anywhere that you can use a path.

arguments.name: LISTING
arguments.description: Writes the trace record to the Listing destination, so that each part of the trace record immediately precedes the output object that it describes.

statements.name: ODS USEGOPT
statements.description: Specifies that ODS use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

statements.name: ODS VERIFY
statements.description: Prints or suppresses a message indicating that a style definition or a table definition being used is not supplied by SAS.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: Prints an error message instead of a warning message and does not send output objects to open destinations.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Suppresses the warning.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Prints the warning and sends output objects to open destinations.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: Prints a warning message and does not send output objects to open destinations.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: Action statement.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: Writes the current observation to a SAS data set.

statements.name: PACKAGE
statements.description: Creates a DS2 package. package specifies the package name. package can be one of these forms. catalog.schema.package schema.package catalog.package package catalog is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. schema is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. package is the name of the package. Requirement: Package naming conventions are based on the data source.

arguments.name: HASH
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the package as HASH to register the hash package for use in a DS2 program.

arguments.name: HITER
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the package as HITER to register the hash iterator package for use in a DS2 program.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: alter-password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The ALTER= option applies only to a SAS data set. You can use this option to assign a password or to access a read-protected, write-protected, or alter-protected file. When you replace a data set that is protected with an ALTER password, the new data set inherits the ALTER password. The password is blotted out when the code is written in the SAS log. For example: set a(alter=XXXXXXX);

arguments.name: AS
arguments.description: Separates the new-name from the old-name.

arguments.name: BUFNO=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: n | nK specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 buffers, and a value of 1k specifies 1024 buffers. hex specifies the number of buffers as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0-9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the number of buffers to 45 buffers. MIN sets the minimum number of buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value for the operating environment. This is the default.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nK
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: hexX
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers as a hexadecimal value. Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: Sets the minimum number of buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value for the operating environment. This is the default.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Sets the number of buffers to the maximum possible number in your operating environment, up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 2³¹-1, or approximately 2 billion.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: n | nK | nM | nG specifies the page size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies a page size of 8 bytes, and a value of 4k specifies a page size of 4096 bytes. hexX specifies the page size as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0-9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the page size to 45 bytes.
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MAX

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nK
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nM
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nG
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: hexX
arguments.description: Specifies the page size as a hexadecimal value. Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Sets the page size to the maximum possible number in your operating environment, up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 2³¹-1, or approximately 2 billion bytes.

arguments.name: BULKLOAD=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: YES calls a DBMS-specific bulk load facility in order to insert or append rows to a DBMS table.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Calls a DBMS-specific bulk load facility in order to insert or append rows to a DBMS table.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Uses the dynamic SAS/ACCESS engine to insert or append data to a DBMS table.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: NO specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are uncompressed (fixed-length records). YES | CHAR specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RLE (Run Length Encoding). RLE compresses observations by reducing repeated consecutive characters (including blanks) to two-byte or three-byte representations. Alias: ON Tip: Use this compression algorithm for character data. Note: COMPRESS=CHAR is accepted by Version 7 and later versions. BINARY specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RDC (Ross Data Compression). RDC combines run-length encoding and sliding-window compression to compress the file.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are uncompressed (fixed-length records).

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RLE (Run Length Encoding). RLE compresses observations by reducing repeated consecutive characters (including blanks) to two-byte or three-byte representations.

arguments.name: CHAR
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RLE (Run Length Encoding). RLE compresses observations by reducing repeated consecutive characters (including blanks) to two-byte or three-byte representations. COMPRESS=CHAR is accepted by Version 7 and later versions.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RDC (Ross Data Compression). RDC combines run-length encoding and sliding-window compression to compress the file.

arguments.name: DBKEY=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: column used by SAS to build an internal WHERE clause to search for matches in the DBMS table based on the key column. For example:

arguments.name: DBNULL=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: _ALL_ specifies that the YES or NO applies to all columns in the table. (This is valid in the interfaces to Informix, Oracle, Sybase, and Teradata only.) YES specifies that the NULL value is valid for the specified columns in the DBMS table. NO specifies that the NULL value is not valid for the specified columns in the DBMS table. column specifies the name of a column. Details: This option is valid only for creating DBMS tables. If you specify more than one column name, the names must be separated with spaces.

arguments.name: DROP=
arguments.description: Arguments: column-list specifies the names of the columns to omit from the output table. Restriction: Numbered range lists in the format col1-col5 and name prefix lists in the format col: are not supported. Details: The DROP= table option specifies that all columns in the column-list should not be included in the creation of output rows. Normally, all columns in the program data vector are included in the output rows. If the drop attribute is specified, all columns not included in the drop statement will be used to create columns in the output rows.

arguments.name: ENCRYPT=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: YES encrypts the file. The encryption method uses passwords. At a minimum, you must specify the READ= or the PW= table option at the same time that you specify ENCRYPT=YES. Because the encryption method uses passwords, you cannot change any password on an encrypted data set without re-creating the data set. NO does not encrypt the file.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Encrypts the file. The encryption method uses passwords. At a minimum, you must specify the READ= or the PW= table option at the same time that you specify ENCRYPT=YES. Because the encryption method uses passwords, you cannot change any password on an encrypted data set without re-creating the data set.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Does not encrypt the file.

arguments.name: EXTENSION=
arguments.description: Specifies that the package is of type hash or hash iterator.

arguments.name: 'HASH'
arguments.description: Specifies that the package is of type hash.

arguments.name: 'HITER'
arguments.description: Specifies that the package is of type hash iterator.

arguments.name: KEEP=
arguments.description: Arguments: column-list specifies the names of the columns to keep in the output table. Restriction: Numbered range lists in the format col1-col5 and name prefix lists in the format col: are not supported. Details: The KEEP= table option specifies that all columns in the column-list should be included in the creation of output rows. Normally, all columns in the program data vector are included in the output rows. If the keep attribute is specified, all columns not included in the KEEP statement will be dropped from the output rows.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Syntax Description:

arguments.name: LOCKTABLE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: SHARE locks a table in shared mode, allowing other users or processes to read data from the tables, but preventing users from updating data. EXCLUSIVE locks a table exclusively, preventing other users from accessing any table that you open. Details: You can lock tables only if you are the owner or have been granted the necessary privilege.

arguments.name: SHARE
arguments.description: Locks a table in shared mode, allowing other users or processes to read data from the tables, but preventing users from updating data.

arguments.name: EXCLUSIVE
arguments.description: Locks a table exclusively, preventing other users from accessing any table that you open.

arguments.name: OVERWRITE=
arguments.description: Arguments: YES | NO specifies whether the output table is deleted before a replacement output table is created or whether a package or thread is dropped. Default: NO

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the output table is deleted before a replacement output table is created or a package or thread is dropped.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the output table is not deleted before a replacement output table is created or a package or thread is dropped.

arguments.name: PW=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The PW= option applies to all types of SAS files. You can use this option to assign a password to a SAS file or to access a password-protected SAS file. When replacing a SAS data set that is protected by an ALTER password, the new data set inherits the ALTER password. When the code is written to the SAS log the password is blotted out, for example: drop thread job2 (pw=xxxxxxx);

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: read-password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The READ= option applies to all types of SAS files except catalogs. You can use this option to assign a password to a SAS file or to access a read-protected SAS file. When the code is written to the SAS log, the password is blotted out, for example: declare package sales (read=XXXXXXX);

arguments.name: RENAME=
arguments.description: Arguments: old-name the column you want to rename. new-name the new name of the column. It must be a valid name for the data source. Details: The RENAME= table option allows you to change the names of one or more columns. If you use RENAME= when you create a table, the new column name is included in the output table. If you use RENAME= on an input table, the new name is used in DS2 programming statements. If you use RENAME= in the same DS2 program with either the DROP= or the KEEP= table option, the DROP= and the KEEP= table options are applied before RENAME=. You must use the old name in the DROP= and KEEP= table options. You cannot drop and rename the same column in the same statement.

arguments.name: SAS_ENCRYPT=
arguments.description: Specifies the encryption algorithm.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS Proprietary algorithm.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: data-set-type specifies the special type of the data set. Details: Use the TYPE= table option to create a special SAS data set in the proper format, or to identify the special type of the SAS data set in a procedure statement.

arguments.name: WRITE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: write-password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The WRITE= option applies to all types of SAS files except catalogs. You can use this option to assign a password to a SAS file or to access a write-protected SAS file. When the code is written to the SAS log, the password is blotted out, for example: drop thread job2a (write=XXXXXXX);

statements.name: PAGE
statements.description: Skips to a new page in the SAS log.

statements.name: PUT
statements.description: Writes lines to the SAS log, to the SAS output window, or to an external location that is specified in the most recent FILE statement.

arguments.name: OVERPRINT
arguments.description: Causes the values that follow the keyword OVERPRINT to print on the most recently written output line.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: Writes the values of all variables, which includes automatic variables, that are defined in the current DATA step by using named output.

arguments.name: _BLANKPAGE_
arguments.description: Advances the pointer to the first line of a new page, even when the pointer is positioned on the first line and the first column of a new page.

arguments.name: _INFILE_
arguments.description: Writes the last input data record that is read either from the current input file or from the data lines that follow a DATELINES statement.

arguments.name: _ODS_
arguments.description: Moves data values for all columns (as defined by the ODS option in the FILE statement) into a special buffer, from which it is eventually written to the data component. The ODS option in the FILE statement defines the structure of the data component that holds the results of the DATA step.

arguments.name: _PAGE_
arguments.description: Advances the pointer to the first line of a new page. SAS automatically begins a new page when a line exceeds the current PAGESIZE= value.

statements.name: PUTLOG
statements.description: Writes a message to the SAS log.

statements.name: RDISPLAY
statements.description: Creates a Log window to display the lines from the log and an Output window to list the output generated from the execution of the statements within an asynchronous RSUBMIT block.

statements.name: REDIRECT
statements.description: Points to different input or output SAS data sets when you execute a stored program.

arguments.name: INPUT
arguments.description: Specifies to redirect input data sets.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Specifies to redirect output data sets.

statements.name: REMOVE
statements.description: Deletes an observation from a SAS data set.

statements.name: RENAME
statements.description: Specifies new names for variables in output SAS data sets.

statements.name: REPLACE
statements.description: Replaces an observation in the same location.

statements.name: RETAIN
statements.description: Causes a variable that is created by an INPUT or assignment statement to retain its value from one iteration of the DATA step to the next.

statements.name: RETURN
statements.description: Stops executing statements at the current point in the DATA step and returns to a predetermined point in the step.

statements.name: RGET
statements.description: Retrieves the log and output that are created by an asynchronous RSUBMIT and merges them into the Log and Output windows of the client session.

statements.name: RSUBMIT
statements.description: Marks the beginning of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session for execution.

statements.name: SET
statements.description: Reads an observation from one or more SAS data sets.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: CUREOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a variable that contains the observation number that was just read from the data set.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator. The variable, which is initialized to zero, is set to 1 when SET reads the last observation of the last data set listed. This variable is not added to any new data set.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.help: FIRSTOBS=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: GENMAX=
arguments.description: Requests generations for a data set and specifies the maximum number of versions.

arguments.name: INDSNAME=
arguments.description: Creates and names a variable that stores the name of the SAS data set from which the current observation is read. The stored name can be a data set name or a physical name. The physical name is the name by which the operating environment recognizes the file.

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: Provides nonsequential access to observations in a SAS data set, which are based on the value of an index variable or a key.

arguments.name: KEYRESET=
arguments.description: Controls whether a KEY= search should begin at the top of the index for the data set that is being read. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 1, the index lookup begins at the top of the index. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 0, the index lookup is not reset and the lookup continues where the prior lookup ended.

arguments.name: NOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable whose value is usually the total number of observations in the input data set or data sets. If more than one data set is listed in the SET statement, NOBS= the total number of observations in the data sets that are listed. The number of observations includes those observations that are marked for deletion but are not yet deleted.

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.help: OBS=n | nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: OPEN=
arguments.description: Allows you to delay the opening of any concatenated SAS data sets until they are ready to be processed.

arguments.name: IMMEDIATE
arguments.description: During the compilation phase, opens all data sets that are listed in the SET statement.

arguments.name: DEFER
arguments.description: Opens the first data set during the compilation phase, and opens subsequent data sets during the execution phase. When the DATA step reads and processes all observations in a data set, it closes the data set and opens the next data set in the list.

arguments.name: POINT=
arguments.description: Specifies a temporary variable whose numeric value determines which observation is read. POINT= causes the SET statement to use random (direct) access to read a SAS data set.

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: Assigns a read password to a SAS file and enables access to a read-protected SAS file.

statements.name: SIGNOFF
statements.description: Ends the connection between a client session and a server session.

statements.name: SIGNON
statements.description: Initiates a connection between a client session and a server session.

statements.name: SKIP
statements.description: Creates a blank line in the SAS log.

statements.name: STOP
statements.description: Stops execution of the current DATA step.

statements.name: SYSTASK
statements.description: Executes, lists, or terminates asynchronous tasks.

statements.name: TABLE
statements.description: ] Begins a DS2 program and provides names for any output tables. <table-expression>::=table (table-options) | _ROWSET_ (table-options) | _NULL_ Without Arguments: If you do not specify any table names with the TABLE|DATA statement, then the DS2 program returns table rows to the client application and no tables are created. Arguments: table specifies the name of the table. table can be one of these forms. catalog.schema.table-name schema.table-name catalog.table-name table-name where: catalog is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. schema is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. table-name is the name of the table. Requirements: Table naming conventions are based on the data source. _ROWSET_ specifies that the DATA statement should not create a table, but it should instead return table rows to the client application. _NULL_ specifies that the DATA statement should not create a table or return rows to the client application. table-options specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it writes rows to the output table.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: alter-password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The ALTER= option applies only to a SAS data set. You can use this option to assign a password or to access a read-protected, write-protected, or alter-protected file. When you replace a data set that is protected with an ALTER password, the new data set inherits the ALTER password. The password is blotted out when the code is written in the SAS log. For example: set a(alter=XXXXXXX);

arguments.name: AS
arguments.description: Separates the new-name from the old-name.

arguments.name: BUFNO=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: n | nK specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 buffers, and a value of 1k specifies 1024 buffers. hex specifies the number of buffers as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0-9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the number of buffers to 45 buffers. MIN sets the minimum number of buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value for the operating environment. This is the default.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nK
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: hexX
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers as a hexadecimal value. Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: Sets the minimum number of buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value for the operating environment. This is the default.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Sets the number of buffers to the maximum possible number in your operating environment, up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 2³¹-1, or approximately 2 billion.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: n | nK | nM | nG specifies the page size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies a page size of 8 bytes, and a value of 4k specifies a page size of 4096 bytes. hexX specifies the page size as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0-9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the page size to 45 bytes.
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MAX

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nK
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nM
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: nG
arguments.description: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). Replace n with an integer value.

arguments.name: hexX
arguments.description: Specifies the page size as a hexadecimal value. Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Sets the page size to the maximum possible number in your operating environment, up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 2³¹-1, or approximately 2 billion bytes.

arguments.name: BULKLOAD=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: YES calls a DBMS-specific bulk load facility in order to insert or append rows to a DBMS table.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Calls a DBMS-specific bulk load facility in order to insert or append rows to a DBMS table.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Uses the dynamic SAS/ACCESS engine to insert or append data to a DBMS table.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: NO specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are uncompressed (fixed-length records). YES | CHAR specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RLE (Run Length Encoding). RLE compresses observations by reducing repeated consecutive characters (including blanks) to two-byte or three-byte representations. Alias: ON Tip: Use this compression algorithm for character data. Note: COMPRESS=CHAR is accepted by Version 7 and later versions. BINARY specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RDC (Ross Data Compression). RDC combines run-length encoding and sliding-window compression to compress the file.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are uncompressed (fixed-length records).

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RLE (Run Length Encoding). RLE compresses observations by reducing repeated consecutive characters (including blanks) to two-byte or three-byte representations.

arguments.name: CHAR

RLE compresses observations by reducing repeated consecutive characters (including blanks) to two-byte or three-byte representations. COMPRESS=CHAR is accepted by Version 7 and later versions.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records) by SAS using RDC (Ross Data Compression). RDC combines run-length encoding and sliding-window compression to compress the file.

arguments.name: DBNULL=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: _ALL_ specifies that the YES or NO applies to all columns in the table. (This is valid in the interfaces to Informix, Oracle, Sybase, and Teradata only.) YES specifies that the NULL value is valid for the specified columns in the DBMS table. NO specifies that the NULL value is not valid for the specified columns in the DBMS table. column specifies the name of a column. Details: This option is valid only for creating DBMS tables. If you specify more than one column name, the names must be separated with spaces.

arguments.name: DROP=
arguments.description: Arguments: column-list specifies the names of the columns to omit from the output table. Restriction: Numbered range lists in the format col1-col5 and name prefix lists in the format col: are not supported. Details: The DROP= table option specifies that all columns in the column-list should not be included in the creation of output rows. Normally, all columns in the program data vector are included in the output rows. If the drop attribute is specified, all columns not included in the drop statement will be used to create columns in the output rows.

arguments.name: ENCRYPT=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: YES encrypts the file. The encryption method uses passwords. At a minimum, you must specify the READ= or the PW= table option at the same time that you specify ENCRYPT=YES. Because the encryption method uses passwords, you cannot change any password on an encrypted data set without re-creating the data set. NO does not encrypt the file.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Encrypts the file. The encryption method uses passwords. At a minimum, you must specify the READ= or the PW= table option at the same time that you specify ENCRYPT=YES. Because the encryption method uses passwords, you cannot change any password on an encrypted data set without re-creating the data set.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Does not encrypt the file.

arguments.name: KEEP=
arguments.description: Arguments: column-list specifies the names of the columns to keep in the output table. Restriction: Numbered range lists in the format col1-col5 and name prefix lists in the format col: are not supported. Details: The KEEP= table option specifies that all columns in the column-list should be included in the creation of output rows. Normally, all columns in the program data vector are included in the output rows. If the keep attribute is specified, all columns not included in the KEEP statement will be dropped from the output rows.

arguments.description: Syntax Description: SHARE locks a table in shared mode, allowing other users or processes to read data from the tables, but preventing users from updating data. EXCLUSIVE locks a table exclusively, preventing other users from accessing any table that you open. Details: You can lock tables only if you are the owner or have been granted the necessary privilege.

arguments.name: PW=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The PW= option applies to all types of SAS files. You can use this option to assign a password to a SAS file or to access a password-protected SAS file. When replacing a SAS data set that is protected by an ALTER password, the new data set inherits the ALTER password. When the code is written to the SAS log the password is blotted out, for example: drop thread job2 (pw=xxxxxxx);

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: read-password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The READ= option applies to all types of SAS files except catalogs. You can use this option to assign a password to a SAS file or to access a read-protected SAS file. When the code is written to the SAS log, the password is blotted out, for example: declare package sales (read=XXXXXXX);

arguments.name: RENAME=
arguments.description: Arguments: old-name the column you want to rename. new-name the new name of the column. It must be a valid name for the data source. Details: The RENAME= table option allows you to change the names of one or more columns. If you use RENAME= when you create a table, the new column name is included in the output table. If you use RENAME= on an input table, the new name is used in DS2 programming statements. If you use RENAME= in the same DS2 program with either the DROP= or the KEEP= table option, the DROP= and the KEEP= table options are applied before RENAME=. You must use the old name in the DROP= and KEEP= table options. You cannot drop and rename the same column in the same statement.

arguments.name: SAS_ENCRYPT=
arguments.description: Specifies the encryption algorithm.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS Proprietary algorithm.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: data-set-type specifies the special type of the data set. Details: Use the TYPE= table option to create a special SAS data set in the proper format, or to identify the special type of the SAS data set in a procedure statement.

arguments.name: WRITE=
arguments.description: Syntax Description: write-password must be a valid SAS name. Details: The WRITE= option applies to all types of SAS files except catalogs. You can use this option to assign a password to a SAS file or to access a write-protected SAS file. When the code is written to the SAS log, the password is blotted out, for example: drop thread job2a (write=XXXXXXX);

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator. This variable is initialized to 0 and is set to 1 when UPDATE processes the last observation. This variable is not added to any data set.

arguments.name: UPDATEMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether missing variable values in a transaction data set are to be allowed to replace existing variable values in a master data set.

arguments.name: MISSINGCHECK
arguments.description: Prevents missing variable values in a transaction data set from replacing values in a master data set.

arguments.name: NOMISSINGCHECK
arguments.description: Allows missing variable values in a transaction data set to replace values in a master data set.

statements.name: WAITFOR
statements.description: Suspends execution of the current SAS session until the specified tasks finish executing.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: Action statement.

arguments.name: ATTR=
arguments.description: Controls these highlighting attributes of the field:

arguments.name: BLINK
arguments.description: Causes the field to blink.

arguments.name: HIGHLIGHT
arguments.description: Displays the field at high intensity.

arguments.name: REV_VIDEO
arguments.description: Displays the field in reverse video.

arguments.name: UNDERLINE
arguments.description: Underlines the field.

arguments.name: AUTOSKIP=
arguments.description: Controls whether the cursor moves to the next unprotected field of the current window or group when you have entered data in all positions of a field.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the cursor moves automatically to the next unprotected field.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the cursor does not move automatically.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the window background for operating environments that have this capability. In other operating environments, this option affects the color of the window border.
arguments.help: COLOR=BLACK | GRAY | PINK | BLUE | GREEN | RED | BROWN | MAGENTA | WHITE | CYAN | ORANGE | YELLOW

arguments.name: BLACK
arguments.description: BLACK

arguments.name: GRAY
arguments.description: GRAY|GREY

arguments.name: PINK
arguments.description: PINK

arguments.name: BLUE
arguments.description: BLUE

arguments.description: GREEN

arguments.description: RED

arguments.description: CYAN

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns in the window.

arguments.name: DISPLAY=
arguments.description: Determines whether the macro processor displays the characters you are entering into a macro variable value as you enter them.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that SAS displays characters in a field as you type them in.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the entered characters are not displayed.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: Specifies a group of related fields.

arguments.name: ICOLUMN=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial column within the monitor at which the window is displayed.

arguments.name: IROW=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial row (or line) within the monitor at which the window is displayed.

arguments.name: KEYS=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a KEYS entry that contains the function key definitions for the window.

arguments.name: MENU=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a menu (pmenu) you have built with the PMENU procedure.

arguments.name: PERSIST=
arguments.description: Controls whether a field is displayed by all executions of a DISPLAY statement in the same iteration of the DATA step until the DISPLAY statement contains the BLANK option.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that each execution of the DISPLAY statement displays all previously displayed contents of the field as well as the contents that are scheduled for display by the current DISPLAY statement. If the new contents overlap persisting contents, the persisting contents are no longer displayed.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that each execution of a DISPLAY statement displays only the current contents of the field.

arguments.name: PROTECT=
arguments.description: Controls whether information can be entered into a field.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that you cannot enter information.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that you can enter information.

arguments.name: REQUIRED=
arguments.description: Controls whether a field can be left blank.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that you must enter a value in the field.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that you can leave the field blank.

arguments.name: ROWS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows (or lines) in the window.
